{{For|the American media executive|Andrew Lack (executive)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Use British English|date=September 2017}} Dr '''Andrew John Lack''' (born 1953) is an English [[biologist]] and author, specializing in [[botany]] and based at [[Oxford Brookes University]].
Andrew Lack is the son of the ornithologist [[David Lack]] (1910–1973).<ref name="anderson">{{cite book| first=Ted R. | last=Anderson | title=The Life of David Lack: Father of Evolutionary Ecology | publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] | year=2013 | isbn=978-0-19-992264-2 }}</ref> He was educated at the [[Dragon School]], [[Oxford]] and [[Bryanston School]], [[Dorset]].<ref>Dust jacket of ''Redbreast: The Robin in Life and Literature'', SMH Books, 2008.</ref> He studied for an undergraduate degree in botany at [[Aberdeen University]] and obtained his doctorate, also in botany, from the [[University of Cambridge]].
Lack was a lecturer at [[Swansea University]] for seven years. In 1987, he became a lecturer in [[biology]] at [[Oxford Brookes University]] where he contributed to modules taught on the Environmental Biology degree, along with contemporaries such as [[Denis Owen]].
Andrew Lack's research is in the area of [[plant reproduction|plant reproductive]] [[ecology]] and [[genetics]], especially [[pollination]], [[tropical rain forest]] ecology, and the history and philosophy of the interaction of humans with the environment.
In 2008, Lack published the book ''Redbreast: The Robin in Life and Literature'', a literary collection based on the [[European robin|robin]].<ref name="telegraph">Christopher Howse, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/non_fictionreviews/3670164/The-Robin-in-life-and-literature.html The Robin in life and literature]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', 27 December 2007.</ref><ref>Clarissa Sebag-Montefiore [http://www.thebookseller.com/news/74869-smh-books-robin-book-success.html SMH Books robin book success] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130204060117/http://www.thebookseller.com/news/74869-smh-books-robin-book-success.html |date=4 February 2013 }}, [http://www.thebookseller.com/ theBookseller.com], 15 January 2009.</ref> This was an updated version of a book published by his father, [[David Lack]].
Andrew Lack is married, has four children, and lives in Oxford. He leads the [[Isis Chamber Orchestra]].{{citation needed|date=May 2015}}
==Books== Lack has written the following books:<ref>[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Books/s?ie=UTF8&rh=n%3A266239%2Cp_27%3AAndrew%20Lack&field-author=Andrew%20Lack&page=1 Books by Andrew Lack], [[Amazon.co.uk]].</ref>
* ''The Natural History of Pollination'', with Michael Proctor and Peter Yeo ([[Harper Collins]], New Naturalist series, No. 83, 1996, {{ISBN|978-0-00-219905-6}}) * ''Instant Notes: Plant Biology'', with David E. Evans ([[BIOS Scientific Publishers]], Instant Notes series, 2001, {{ISBN|978-0-387-91613-2}}) * ''The Museum Swifts'', with Roy Overall ([[Oxford University Museum of Natural History]], 2002) * ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=biFOZ3aK8i8C Instant Notes: Plant Biology]'', 2nd edition, with David E. Evans ([[Taylor & Francis]], Instant Notes series, 2005, {{ISBN|978-0-415-35643-5}}) * ''Redbreast: The Robin in Life and Literature''<ref name="telegraph" /> ([[SMH Books]], 2008, {{ISBN|978-0-9553827-2-7}}) * ''Poppy'' ([[Reaktion]], 2016, {{ISBN|978-1-780-23653-7}})
He has contributed to:
* ''Silent Summer'' ed. Norman Maclean ([[Cambridge University Press]] 2010, {{ISBN|978-0-521-51966-3}}) * ''Nature Tales'' comp. Michael Allen & Sonya Patel Ellis (Elliott and Thompson 2010, {{ISBN|978-1-904027-94-2}})
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://bms.brookes.ac.uk/staff/dr-andrew-lack Dr Andrew Lack home page] * [https://www.facebook.com/groups/49342217223/ Andrew Lack Fan Club], [[Facebook]]
{{authority control}}

[[File:Airmassesorigin.png|300px|thumb|right|Different air masses which affect North America, as well as other continents, tend to be separated by frontal boundaries. In this illustration, the Arctic front separates Arctic from Polar air masses, while the Polar front separates Polar air from warm air masses. (cA is continental arctic; cP is continental polar; mP is maritime polar; cT is continental tropic; and mT is maritime tropic.)]] The '''Arctic front''' is the semipermanent, semi-continuous [[weather front]] between the cold arctic [[air mass]] and the warmer air of the [[polar cells|polar cell]]. It can also be defined as the southern boundary of the Arctic air mass.{{Cite web | last = Zaitseva | first = Nina A. | title = Arctic front | work = Arctic Climatology and Meteorology: Glossary | publisher = National Snow and Ice Data Center | date = | url = http://nsidc.org/arcticmet/glossary/arctic_front.html | accessdate = 2010-11-14| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101126091914/http://nsidc.org/arcticmet/glossary/arctic_front.html| archivedate= 26 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} Mesoscale cyclones known as [[polar low]]s can form along the arctic front in the wake of [[extratropical cyclone]]s. Arctic air masses in their wake are shallow with a deep layer of stable air above the shallow cold cool.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-tBa1DWYoDIC&pg=PA167&lpg=PA167&dq=arctic+front+formation+weather+book&source=bl&ots=Il_EQqptoo&sig=xF2QczKHzcYwLCSD6rAq-0Le_Yw&hl=en&sa=X&ei=EgRIT5GoFuf50gH38qSADw&ved=0CEsQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=arctic%20front%20formation%20weather%20book&f=false|pages=163–172|title=Polar lows: mesoscale weather systems in the polar regions|author=Erik A. Rasmussen and John Turner|year=2003|accessdate=2012-02-24|publisher=Cambridge University Press|ISBN=978-0-521-62430-5}} ==Appearance in satellite images== Arctic Fronts form in the Arctic region, and move southwards in southerly flows. When they reach Northern Europe, they have usually travelled over an open sea, and convective cloudiness has developed. The appearance of an Arctic Cold Fronts is then, essentially, that of a shallow Cold Front. Arctic Cold Fronts are usually so far north that [[Meteosat]] images alone are inadequate to recognize them. Also, the following conceptual models may look like Arctic Cold Fronts: polar Cold Front, Polar Low and Comma. The final check is best made using a loop of AVHRR images with the help of numerical model parameter fields. ==Types of Arctic cold fronts== Arctic Cold Fronts can be classified into two types: *'''Baroclinic fronts'''
These fronts resemble polar cold fronts, but are usually not so extensive. The frontal cloudiness becomes more convective with time. *'''Ice/sea boundary fronts'''
These fronts form over the ice/sea boundary and move southwards with the basic flow. There is only an isolated Cold Front. Often this type is so shallow and weak that it can not be detected in Meteosat water vapour images. == See also == *[[Polar climate]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} [[Category:Atmospheric dynamics]] [[Category:Environment of the Arctic]] [[Category:Weather fronts]] {{Arctic-stub}} {{Climate-stub}}

{{Infobox protected area | name = Audra State Park | iucn_category = III | iucn_ref = <ref name="IUCN1">{{cite web|title=Audra State Park|url=https://www.protectedplanet.net/audra-state-park|website=Protected Planet|publisher=IUCN|accessdate=30 April 2018}}</ref> <!-- images --> | photo = Audra State Park.jpg | photo_caption = [[Middle Fork River]] <!-- map --> | map = USA West Virginia | map_image = | map_size = | map_caption = Location of Audra State Park in West Virginia | relief = 1 <!-- location --> | location = [[Barbour County, West Virginia|Barbour]] & [[Upshur County, West Virginia|Upshur]], West Virginia, United States | nearest_city = | nearest_town = | coordinates = {{coord|39|02|25|N|80|03|55|W|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = <!-- stats --> | length = | length_mi = | length_km = | width = | width_mi = | width_km = | area_acre = 355 | area_ref = | elevation = {{convert|1811|ft|m|abbr=on}} | elevation_avg = | elevation_min = | elevation_max = | dimensions = | designation = <!-- dates & info --> | authorized = | created = | designated = | established = 1950<ref name="WPaNM">{{cite book|title=Where People and Nature Meet: A History of the West Virginia State Parks|publisher=Pictorial Histories Publishing Company|location=[[Charleston, West Virginia|Charleston]], [[West Virginia]]|date=April 1988|isbn=0-933126-91-3}}</ref> | named_for = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_ref = | governing_body = | administrator = | operator = | owner = <!-- website, embedded --> | website = {{URL|https://wvstateparks.com/park/audra-state-park/}} | embedded = }} '''Audra State Park''' is a [[West Virginia]] [[state park]] located on {{convert|355|acre|km2}}<ref>Carrol, S. and Miller, M., ''Hiking West Virginia'', p.92, Globe Pequot Press, Guilford, CT (2003).</ref> in southwestern [[Barbour County, West Virginia|Barbour County]]. It was established around the remnants of an early 19th-century [[gristmill]] and the tiny community of [[Audra, West Virginia|Audra]]. A gristmill spillway is still visible in the river.<ref>[http://www.audrastatepark.com/recreation.html Audra State Park web page, accessed March 16, 2008.]</ref> {{stack|[[File:AlumCave.jpg|thumb|Icicles drape Alum Cave on a winter afternoon]]}} The park is a hilly, secondary forest area bisected by the [[Middle Fork River]]. The deep pools, large, flat rocks, and riverside beach have provided generations of campers, local teens and college students a place to swim or work on their tans.<ref>Crockett, M., "''Jewels in our Crown''", Pictoria Histories, Charleston, WV, 2004. {{ISBN|1-891852-35-3}}</ref> Audra State Park is the site of [[Alum Cave]], which is accessible by a [[boardwalk]] built along this overhanging sandstone ledge.
The park serves as the put-in point for a 6.6 mile [[kayak]] run along about 2.8 miles the Middle Fork River and about 3.8 miles of the [[Tygart Valley River]] to the confluence of the latter with the [[Buckhannon River]].<ref>[http://www.americanwhitewater.org/rivers/id/2455/ American Whitewater web site, Middle Fork River page, accessed July 19, 2006.]</ref>
==Features== * 67 camp sites * Swimming in the Middle Fork River * Hiking trails * Kayaking in the Middle Fork River * Picnic area
==Accessibility==
[[Accessibility]] for the [[disable]]d was assessed by [[West Virginia University]]. The assessment found the campground, picnic area, and park offices to be accessible.<ref>[http://www.cedwvu.org/programs/realchoice/recreation/ ''Guide to Accessible Recreation and Travel in WV'', WVU Center for Excellence in Disabilities web site, accessed July 31, 2006] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060720230618/http://www.cedwvu.org/programs/realchoice/recreation/ |date=July 20, 2006 }}</ref> The main swimming hole (just below the site of the former gristmill), with wet, slippery rocks and unpaved approaches is not considered accessible.
==See also== {{stack|{{Portal|West Virginia}}}} *[[List of West Virginia state parks]]
==References==
{{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|https://wvstateparks.com/park/audra-state-park/}}

{{Infobox ecoregion | name = Bahia interior forests | image = REBIO MAta Escura MG.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = [[Mata Escura Biological Reserve]], in [[Minas Gerais]], [[Brazil]]. | country = {{BRA}} | country1 = | country2 = | state = [[Bahia]] | state1 = [[Espírito Santo]] | state2 = [[Minas Gerais]] | state3 = [[Rio de Janeiro (state)|Rio de Janeiro]] | state4 = [[São Paulo (state)|São Paulo]] | border = [[Serra do Mar coastal forests]] | border1 = [[Bahia coastal forests]] | border2 = [[Caatinga]] | border3 = [[Cerrado]] | bird_species = 540<ref name = "Atlas"> {{cite book |last1 = Hoekstra |first1 = J. M. |last2 = Molnar |first2 = J. L. |last3 = Jennings |first3 = M. |last4 = Revenga |first4 = C. |last5 = Spalding |first5 = M. D. |last6 = Boucher |first6 = T. M. |last7 = Robertson |first7 = J. C. |last8 = Heibel |first8 = T. J. |last9 = Ellison |first9 = K. |title = The Atlas of Global Conservation: Changes, Challenges, and Opportunities to Make a Difference |publisher = [[University of California Press]] |editor1-last = Molnar |editor1-first = J. L. |year = 2010 |isbn = 978-0-520-26256-0 |url=http://www.nature.org/ourscience/sciencefeatures/conservation-atlas-1.xml }}</ref> | mammal_species = 182<ref name = "Atlas"/> | habitat_loss = 69.3 | habitat_loss_ref = <ref name = "Atlas"/> | protected = 1.10 | protected_ref = <ref name = "Atlas"/> | area = 230880 | biome = [[Atlantic Forest]] | map = Bahia interior forests.png | map_size = 240 | map_alt = | map_caption = Localization of Bahia interior forests ecorregion as delineated by [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]]. }} The '''Bahia interior forests''' is an [[ecoregion]] of eastern [[Brazil]]. It is part of the larger [[Atlantic forests]] [[biome]] complex, and lies between the [[Bahia coastal forests]] and the dry shrublands and savannas of Brazil's interior.
==Setting== The Bahia interior forests cover an area of {{convert|230,000|km2|sqmi|sp=us}}, extending across portions of [[Bahia]], [[Espirito Santo]], [[Minas Gerais]], [[Rio de Janeiro state|Rio de Janeiro]], and [[Sergipe]] states. The Bahia interior forests lie inland from the [[Bahia coastal forests]], which extend approximately {{convert|150|km|mi|abbr=on}} inland from the coast. The Bahia interior forests extend north to the [[São Francisco River]], where they lie much closer to the coast, and are bounded on the west by the dry [[Caatinga]] shrublands. Moving south, the forests extend further inland to the [[Paraíba do Sul River|Rio Paraíba do Sul]], [[Rio Preto (Bahia)|Rio Preto]], and [[Rio Grande, Minas Gerais|Rio Grande]], which form the boundary with the [[Paraná-Paraíba interior forests]] to the southwest.
==Flora== Atlantic forest in [[Minas Gerais]], interior [[Bahia]] and southern [[Espírito Santo]], according to [[Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics|IBGE]], consists of a semi-deciduous or deciduous forest.<ref name="ibgemap">{{cite web|title=Mapa da área de Aplicação da Lei nº 11.428 de 2006 |url=ftp://geoftp.ibge.gov.br/mapas_tematicos/mapas_murais/lei11428_mata_atlantica.pdf |publisher=[[Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics|IBGE]] |date=2012-07-28 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In this ecoregion is found a highly threatened spicies, the "Brazilian rosewood" ''([[Dalbergia nigra]])''.<ref name="wwf">{{WWF ecoregion|name=Bahia interior forests|id=nt0104}}</ref>
==Fauna== [[File:Brachyteles hypoxanthus4.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Northern muriqui]] is an endareged species of Bahia interior forests.]] This ecoregion is poorly known. Recently, a new primate species was described, the [[Coimbra Filho's titi]], and other primate, the [[Northern muriqui]] is endemic of Bahia interior forests ecoregion.
==Conservation and threats== [[File:Bahia interior forests WWF satelite.jpg|thumb|right|Satellite picture of Bahia interior forests ecoregion (black line). In this image, it's possible to observe the deforestation degree of the ecoregion.]] Bahia interior forest is one of the most modified ecoregions in Atlantic forest region. Most forests remnants has less than 10 km², and even these are currently under strong pressure from anthropogenic activities, as fires, illegal deforestation and predatory hunting.<ref name="wwf"/> Less than 2 percent of Bahia interior forests are protected as conservation units. The largest forest remnant of this ecoregion is the [[Rio Doce State Park]], with 359 km² of area.<ref name="wwf"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Distinguish|Ben Karlin}} {{Good article}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Ben Carlin | image = BenCarlin01.jpg | image_size = | alt = Refer to caption | caption = Carlin in [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada, in 1948 | birth_name = Frederick Benjamin Carlin | birth_date = 27 July 1912 | birth_place = [[Northam, Western Australia]], Australia | death_date = 7 March 1981 (age 68) | death_place = [[Perth, Western Australia]] | education = [[Guildford Grammar School]]
[[Western Australian School of Mines|Kalgoorlie School of Mines]] | occupation = Engineer, soldier | spouse = Gertrude Plath (m. 1940–?)
Elinore Arone (m. 1946–55)
Cynthia Henderson (m. 1963–64) | partner = | children = Deidre Scott Carlin (b. 1964) }} '''Frederick Benjamin''' "'''Ben'''" '''Carlin''' (27 July 1912 – 7 March 1981) was an Australian adventurer who was the first and only person to [[Circumnavigation|circumnavigate]] the world in an [[amphibious vehicle]]. Born in [[Northam, Western Australia|Northam]], [[Western Australia]], Carlin attended [[Guildford Grammar School]] in [[Perth]], and later studied [[mining engineering]] at the [[Western Australian School of Mines|Kalgoorlie School of Mines]]. After qualifying as an engineer, he worked on the [[Goldfields-Esperance|Goldfields]] before in 1939 emigrating to China to work in a British coal mine. In the [[World War II|Second World War]], Carlin was posted to the [[Indian Army Corps of Engineers]], serving in India, Italy, and throughout the Middle East. After his discharge from service in 1946, he emigrated to the United States with his American wife, Elinore (née Arone). Sparked by an idea he had had whilst in the military, Carlin proposed that the couple honeymoon by crossing the [[Atlantic Ocean]] in a modified [[Ford GPA]] (an amphibious version of the [[Ford GPW]] Jeep), which they named the ''Half-Safe''. Beginning their trip in [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada, the Carlins finally completed the [[transatlantic crossing]] in 1951, after unsuccessful attempts. From there, they travelled to Europe, temporarily settling in [[Birmingham]] to raise more money. They resumed their journey in 1954, travelling overland through the Middle East before arriving in [[Kolkata|Calcutta]]. After a short fundraising trip to Australia, Carlin's wife left to return to the United States. He resumed the journey with new partners, travelling through South-East Asia and the Far East to the northern tip of Japan, and then to [[Alaska]]. After an extended tour through the United States and Canada, he and ''Half-Safe'' finally returned to Montreal, having travelled over {{convert|17,000|km|mi}} by sea and {{convert|62,000|km|mi}} by land during a ten-year journey. Following Carlin's death in 1981, ''Half-Safe'' was acquired by Guildford Grammar, his old school, where it remains on display. ==Early life and military service== Frederick Benjamin Carlin was born on 27 July 1912 in [[Northam, Western Australia|Northam]], [[Western Australia]], a small town in the state's [[Wheatbelt (Western Australia)|Wheatbelt]]. His mother, the former Charlotte Amelia Bramwell, died when he was four,[https://web.archive.org/web/20110822215712/http://www.ggs.wa.edu.au/getdoc/95134e69-cc15-4d30-8d65-5ee8c293eb10/Bulletin_270711.aspx From the archives: a personal glimpse of Ben Carlin] – Guildford Grammar School Weekly Bulletin, Week 1, Term 3, 2011. Published 27 July 2011. Retrieved 1 October 2012. and he was raised by his father, Frederick Cecil Carlin, who was an electrical engineer employed with the [[Western Australian Government Railways]]."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article39086137 NEWSREEL – PERSONALITIES – Honeymoon in Jeep]" – ''[[Western Mail (Western Australia)|The Western Mail]]''. Published 19 August 1948. At the age of ten, Carlin was sent to board at [[Guildford Grammar School]] in [[Perth]].[http://www.ggs.wa.edu.au/About-Us/History.aspx History: Ben Carlin and the Half Safe Story] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121213192612/http://www.ggs.wa.edu.au/About-Us/History.aspx |date=13 December 2012 }} – Guildford Grammar. Retrieved 1 October 2012. Leaving school in 1929, he enrolled at the [[Western Australian School of Mines|School of Mines]] in [[Kalgoorlie]], where he studied [[mining engineering]]. Once he had qualified as an engineer, he worked for a period of time in the surrounding [[Goldfields-Esperance|Goldfields region]]. However, in 1939, he moved to [[Beijing|Peking]], [[China]], to work for a British coal mining company."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article69068340 JEEP TOURIST HAS SEEN THE WORLD]" – ''Advocate''. Published 15 January 1948. Upon the outbreak of the [[World War II|Second World War]], Carlin enlisted in the [[British Indian Army|Indian Army]]. Before leaving for India, he married Gertrude Plath, a German citizen who had been living in China with her aunt and uncle. The couple wed on 20 April 1940, at [[Tianjin|Tientsin]], although they separated before the end of the war."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article38413989 FAMILY NOTICES: MARRIAGES]" – ''[[Western Mail (Western Australia)|The Western Mail]]''. Published 20 June 1940. Having originally enlisted at [[Shanghai]], Carlin was later posted to the [[Madras Engineer Group|Madras Sappers]] in the [[Indian Army Corps of Engineers]]. In August 1941, he was promoted to the position of [[second lieutenant]], as part of a number of "emergency commissions" made at the start of the conflict.{{London Gazette|issue=35256|date=22 August 1941|pages=4883–4884}} During the war, Carlin served in India, Iraq, Persia, Palestine, Syria, and Italy,"[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article69067688 Round the World In a Jeep]" – ''Advocate''. Published 12 January 1948. Retrieved 2 October 2012. and by the conflict's end had been promoted to the rank of [[Major (rank)|major]].Stanton, Kerry (1999). [http://www.collectorcafe.com/article_archive.asp?article=420&id=1481 Half Safe, Half Boat, Half Car and Half a Century] – Collector C@fe. Originally published in ''Army Motors'' magazine, issue 89, 1999. Retrieved 2 October 2012. Towards the end of the war, he met an American [[Red Cross]] nurse, Elinore Arone, who was originally from [[Boston]]. On his discharge from service in 1946, the couple emigrated to [[Maryland]], where they eventually married, in June 1948. ==Circumnavigation== ===''Half-Safe'' and early preparation=== [[File:BenAndElinoreCarlin01.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The Carlins during the early stages of preparation for their journey]] Throughout the war, [[Allies of World War II|the Allies]] had made use of a number of different varieties of [[amphibious vehicle]]. One of the more commonly used was the [[Ford GPA]], a modified version of the [[Ford GPW]] [[Jeep]] (also known as a "Seep").[http://www.4wdonline.com/Mil/Seep/Seep.html Amphibious Jeep] – 4wdonline. Retrieved 2 October 2012. In India towards the end of the war, Carlin had noticed a GPA in an army vehicle lot. To the mockery of his fellow engineers, he suggested that the vehicle could be used to take him around the world, supposedly remarking: "with a bit of titivation, you could go around the world in one of those things"."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1798&dat=19560823&id=EQYdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=z4oEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7005,1828535 'Half-Safe' Is Half Way 'Round World]" – ''[[Sarasota Journal]]''. Published 23 August 2012.Strohl, Daniel (2011). [http://blog.hemmings.com/index.php/2011/03/02/ambitious-amphibious-ben-carlins-round-the-world-trek-in-a-ford-gpa/ Ambitious Amphibious: Ben Carlin's round-the-world trek in a Ford GPA] – Hemmings Daily. Published 2 March 2011. Retrieved 2 October 2012. This idea remained with Carlin after his marriage, and he proposed to his wife that the couple [[honeymoon]] by crossing the [[Atlantic Ocean]] in a modified GPA. After a considerable amount of trouble, the Carlins finally managed to purchase a 1942 Ford GPA (serial number 1239) from a government auction in [[Washington, D.C.]], for [[United States dollar|US$]]901 ($9500 in 2018 dollars). The vehicle had originally been manufactured at [[Ford]]'s plant in [[River Rouge, Michigan]], one of 12,778 built during the war. He originally tried to convince Ford to sponsor his proposed trip, but the company refused, believing the craft would not make the journey. The vehicle required a number of modifications to make it seaworthy, including the addition of a more boat-like [[Bow (ship)|bow]], a [[rudder]], a larger cabin, and two extra fuel tanks – one at the bow and one under the "belly" of the craft, at the [[stern]].[http://www.amphibiousvehicle.net/amphi/H/halfsafespecial/halfsafe.html Half safe (1947 1958)] – Amphibious Vehicles. Retrieved 2 October 2012. Inside the cabin, a [[bunk bed|bunk]] was installed, and the [[dashboard|dash]] was modified to include aircraft instruments, as well as a [[two-way radio]] (including a [[Wireless Set No. 19|19-set]] [[transmitter]] and [[receiver (radio)|receiver]]). In total, the vessel's length was extended by three feet to {{Convert|18|ft|m}}, and the fuel capacity to 200 gallons (760 L) from the original 12 gallons (45 L).[http://www.4wdonline.com/Mil/HalfSafe.html The Amphibious Jeep 'Half Safe'] – 4wdonline. Retrieved 2 October 2012. The construction of the under-belly fuel tank allowed it to be jettisoned when empty, reducing further its full weight of three [[ton]]s (6,720 lb or 3,048 kg).[http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/32360/20051010-0000/www.diggerhistory.info/pages-armour/amphib/allied.htm The Swimmers: Ducks, Larks, and other "birds"] – Digger History. Archived by the [[National Library of Australia]]. Retrieved 2 October 2012. The vessel was christened ''Half-Safe'', after the slogan of [[Arrid]], a deodorant brand – ''"Don't be half-safe – use Arrid to be sure"''. ===Failure of first attempts=== The couple began testing their craft in 1947, and experienced problems with [[carbon monoxide]] removal, with the vessel's enclosed structure potentially increasing the risks of [[carbon monoxide poisoning]]. The Carlins chose [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada, as the official starting point of their [[circumnavigation]] attempt. They set out from the city in late 1947 for [[New York City]], where they were to launch ''Half-Safe'' for the first time, with the intention of crossing the Atlantic via the [[Azores]]. A trial run was made in early January 1948, watched by "crowds of sceptical waterside workers"."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2735690 TO CIRCLE THE WORLD IN AMPHIBIOUS JEEP]" – ''[[The Canberra Times]]''. Published 23 January 1948. The couple's first attempt to complete the [[transatlantic crossing]] occurred on 16 June 1948, launching from [[New York Harbor]]. Cheered on by "100 amazed wharf labourers", they were first washed up-river by a strong tide, but then made their way out into the Atlantic at a speed of five [[Knot (unit)|knots]]."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article46916101 HONEYMOON IN JEEP: Unique enterprise begins] – ''[[The West Australian]]''. Published 18 June 1948. The Carlins failed to maintain radio contact, prompting a search by the [[United States Coast Guard]]."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article56819926 ALARM OVER JEEP AT SEA]" – ''Morning Bulletin''. Published 21 June 1948. The craft was eventually landed five days after its departure, {{convert|40|mi|km}} south of New York City near the [[Shark River Inlet|Shark River inlet]] in [[New Jersey]]."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article59482970 WA Man's Journey]" – ''[[Sunday Times (Western Australia)|The Sunday Times]]''. Published 4 July 1948. The couple had experienced problems with the steering gear and rudder, which made the vessel unable to steer at sea unless the wheel was constantly manned."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article56822622 Round The World In A "DUCK"]" – ''Morning Bulletin''. Published 6 July 1948. With ''Half-Safe'' sailed back to New York, the Carlins commenced their journey for a second time on 3 July,[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article83754945 JEEP TRAVELLERS ARE LOST AGAIN] – ''[[Daily News (Perth, Western Australia)|The Daily News]]''. Published 9 July 1948. but were once again forced back to shore a few days later, this time after nearly being [[asphyxiation|asphyxiated]] due to a cracked [[exhaust pipe]]. [[File:HalfSafe01 – Statue of Liberty.jpg|thumb|left|300px|The Carlins sailed past the [[Statue of Liberty]] in [[New York Harbor]] on one of their first circumnavigation attempts in 1948.]] A third attempt was made in late July, but was again not successful due to the mechanical troubles and heavy [[seasickness]] the Carlins experienced."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article83756203? Jeep Pair Are Safe]" – ''[[Daily News (Perth, Western Australia)|The Daily News]]''. Published 29 July 1948."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article67843264 An Atlantic Venture: Australian in a Jeep – THIRD ATTEMPT FAILS]" – ''Geraldton Guardian''. Published 5 August 1948. The Carlins set out for a fourth time in early August, and progressed further, being sighted several days after their launch by an American [[destroyer]] almost {{convert|200|mi|km}} off of New York.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article22682164 "JEEP" ADVENTURERS DECLINE HELP]" – ''[[The Argus (Australia)|The Argus]]''. Published 13 August 1948. However, the couple soon lost radio contact, prompting [[Pan-American Airways]] to direct their crews to search for their craft."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article79684756 Planes On Alert For Carlins]" – ''[[Daily News (Perth, Western Australia)|The Daily News]]''. Published 25 August 1948. ''Half-Safe'' and the Carlins were finally rescued approximately {{convert|270|mi|km}} off New York by the [[oil tanker]] ''New Jersey'', bound for [[Halifax (former city)|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]]."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article79694344 Carlin Safe Again]" – ''[[Daily News (Perth, Western Australia)|The Daily News]]''. Published 26 August 1948. Seven days into the voyage, a propeller bearing had welded itself fast due to lack of lubrication, leaving the vessel to drift aimlessly for a further ten days without means of steering it or navigating. According to a message Carlin radioed from the tanker to his friends in New York, the couple "drifted and fished", enjoying a "pleasant life, cheaper than [[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]]"."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article47124788 TO START AGAIN: Carlins' Atlantic Experiences]" – ''[[The West Australian]]''. Published 28 August 1948. At the time of the couple's rescue, he considered abandoning the entire voyage, but was convinced to continue by the tanker's Norwegian captain, who greeted Carlin with the words: "Hell, you're not going to leave that god-damned Jeep lying around?!" ===Transatlantic crossing=== The Carlins' fourth failed attempt in two months led them to abandon the project for a period of time in order to raise more money. With the ''New Jersey'' arriving in Halifax two weeks after their rescue, Carlin took up a position with a local [[marine salvage]] firm, while his wife returned to her family in Boston, and worked in a law office."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GC0sAAAAIBAJ&sjid=39wFAAAAIBAJ&dq=ben-carlin&pg=4835%2C16347 Start Perilous Atlantic Trip In Amphibious Jeep] – ''[[Ottawa Citizen]]''. Published 1 September 1949. One final attempt was considered in November 1948, but postponed due to the approaching winter weather, with ''Half-Safe'' stored in a Halifax garage.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article80801570 CARLINS POSTPONE SIXTH TRY] – ''[[Daily News (Perth, Western Australia)|The Daily News]]''. Published 19 November 1948. In mid 1949, the couple began to ready ''Half-Safe'' for a further attempt at the crossing. Testing in late August revealed a burnt-out clutch,[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article22775112 ATLANTIC BID IN JEEP POSTPONED] – ''[[The Argus (Australia)|The Argus]]''. Published 30 August 1949. which was repaired, and Carlin recognised the need for much larger amounts of fuel. To achieve this extra capacity, two fuel tanks were tied behind ''Half-Safe'', painted bright yellow to aid visibility from the air. Further alterations were also made to the craft's [[superstructure]], and extra stabilising rudders were added. The Carlins launched again in early September 1949. When the vessel was {{Convert|35|mi|km}} off shore, both of the auxiliary fuel tanks were lost, necessitating return to Halifax."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6SFlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-4cNAAAAIBAJ&dq=ben-carlin&pg=6485%2C336090 Misadventure Pursues Couple's Sea-Going Jeep]" – ''[[Edmonton Journal]]''. Published 2 September 1949. Carlin almost decided to abandon the journey and liquidate ''Half-Safe'', but was convinced by his wife to continue. {{Quote box |quote = When they struck a hurricane between the Azores and Madeira, and the superstructure looked like caving in, he got Elinore to recite the escape drill out loud in the tumult: "You shout 'OUT' – I get out and wait. You follow and grab the gear. I follow you – KEEP IN CONTACT!" They couldn't inflate and board the raft in that sea, and provided that the equipment wasn't wrenched from their grip they should be able to go on living, even though they carried no life jackets, for both were strong swimmers. He warned her: "Keep your face down and away from the spray – it hurts." |source = – ''The Buckingham Post'', 27 January 1956"[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SNswAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9uEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2949,150212&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en Crossed Atlantic In A Jeep]" – ''Buckingham Post''. Published 27 January 1956. |align = right |width = 30% |fontsize = 80% }} Over the following six months, the Carlins again made modifications to their vessel, with the most important being a large, purpose-built tank that was to be towed behind the craft. This increased the total fuel capacity of ''Half-Safe'' to 735 gallons (3,337 L), with the vessel also carrying 30 gallons (136 L) of water, eight gallons (36 L) of oil, and six weeks' worth of provisions. The couple left Halifax on 19 July 1950, and, after a 32-day voyage, arrived on [[Flores Island (Azores)|Flores]], the most westerly island of the Azores. Their landing was well-received, with ''[[Life (magazine)|LIFE]]'' featuring the crossing in a multiple-page article later that year, which also featured many of the Carlins' photographs.{{cite book| author = Time Inc| title = LIFE| url = https://books.google.com/?id=AEwEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA149| date = 20 November 1950| publisher = Time Inc| page = 149 }} However, the journey had not occurred without mishap – Carlin was forced to remove the cylinder head several times in order to clean the carbon from the valves and replace the head [[gasket]], and the couple lost radio contact halfway through the voyage, leading to fears they had been lost at sea. From Flores, the couple progressed to [[Horta (Azores)|Horta]] on the island of [[Faial Island|Faial]], a distance of {{convert|150|mi|km}}."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7BFVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FpMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1517,3576832&hl=en "Floating Jeep" Feared Lost, Reaches Azores]" – ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]''. Published 20 August 1950. They then travelled to [[Madeira]], having obtained surplus fuel from a passing Portuguese cruiser midway through the trip."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article42703140 SEA-GOING JEEP SAFE]" – ''[[Cairns Post]]''. Published 15 December 1950. Although originally expected to head directly to [[Lisbon]], [[Portugal]], from Madeira,"[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=64EtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=U5kFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2022,6963853&hl=en Carlins Readying Jeep For Horta–Lisbon Lap]" – ''[[The Montreal Gazette]]''. Published 26 August 1950. the couple instead chose to head for [[Morocco]] via the [[Canary Islands]], coming ashore at [[Cap Juby]] in the Spanish territory of [[Rio de Oro]] on 23 February 1951.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27014135 CROSSED ATLANTIC IN JEEP] – ''[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]]''. Published 16 March 1951. From Cap Juby, the Carlins drove north through the coastal regions of Morocco to Europe. The hot daytime temperatures, which reportedly reached {{convert|170|F|C}} within the vehicle's cabin, necessitated that ''Half-Safe'' be driven exclusively at night. The vehicle reached [[Casablanca]], [[French Morocco]], on 16 March 1951, and the British territory of [[Gibraltar]] in mid April, after it was sailed across the [[Straits of Gibraltar]].[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18209630 Sea-going Jeep Turns Up At Gibraltar] – ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]''. Published 23 April 1951. From there, the Carlins drove through a number of European countries, where they engaged in sight-seeing, before finally sailing across the [[English Channel]] and concluding the first part of their journey in [[Birmingham]], where they arrived on 1 January 1952.[http://www.goodsdirect.net/halfsafe.html Half safe] – goodsdirect.net. Retrieved 2 October 2012. ===Europe and the Middle East=== [[File:HalfSafe02 – Copenhagen.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The Carlins and ''Half-Safe'' were greeted by a large crowd upon landing in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]], in 1951.]] Tired, weary, and lacking in money, the Carlins decided to remain in England to rest and recuperate. Throughout the journey from Nova Scotia to the Azores, both Carlin and his wife had suffered from severe [[hallucination]]s, including one instance where he had jerked awake to find himself 60° off course. Another important objective of their time in Britain was to repair ''Half-Safe'', which had sustained large amounts of damage during the crossing, not least from [[1950 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Charlie|Hurricane Charlie]], which battered the vessel whilst it was amongst the islands of [[Macaronesia]]. The repairs to the craft were accomplished with the help of [[Royal Air Force|RAF]] Group Captain Malcolm Bunting, who had served alongside Carlin in India. To raise money for the continuation of the journey, ''Half-Safe'' was exhibited in [[department stores]] throughout Europe. During this time, Carlin also completed ''Half Safe: Across the Atlantic by Jeep'', a book chronicling the first half of their journey, which sold 32,000 copies and was translated into five languages. The book was generally well received, with a reviewer in ''[[The Montreal Gazette]]'' describing Carlin as "an adventurer of the old school – full of the explorer's instinct, and with a dry wit that makes his story an odd mixture of high-adventure and real understatement".Timmins, Terry (1955). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=roAtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MZkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3830,2365958&dq=ben-carlin+dry+wit&hl=en Amphibious Jaunt]" – ''[[The Montreal Gazette]]''. Published 10 November 1955. The Carlins set out again in early 1955, arriving in France on 22 April 1955. The vehicle continued through [[Switzerland]], [[northern Italy]], and [[Yugoslavia]], where in May 1955, it was reported that ''Half-Safe'' had had its first [[flat tire]], whilst travelling through [[Belgrade]].[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/2063165502.html?FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=May+07%2C+1955&author=&pub=Daily+Boston+Globe+%281928-1960%29&desc=Round-World+Jeep+Gets+First+Flat+Tire&pqatl=google Round-World Jeep Gets First Flat Tire] – ''[[Boston Globe]]''. Published 7 May 1955. The Carlins then continued through [[Greece]] and [[Turkey]], sailing across the [[Bosphorus]] to [[Asia Minor]], before progressing through Syria, [[Jordan]], Iraq, Iran, and [[Pakistan]] to [[Calcutta]], India. Carlin later noted: "the 2000 miles across the Atlantic from Nova Scotia to the Azores were in many ways much less worrying than a similar distance covered on murderous roads in Persia"."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FxsRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FpUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5747,182554&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en Going Round World in Floating Jeep]" – ''[[The Age]]''. Published 2 November 1955. At Calcutta, the Carlins decided to transport ''Half-Safe'' to [[Australia]] via steamer. At the start of his voyage, Carlin had said he would not travel to Australia or New Zealand, because petrol was "too dear" there. However, a lack of funding meant the side trip was necessary. The trip also allowed Carlin to meet with his family, who still lived in Perth – his brother, Tom Carlin, had become a [[Captain (naval)|captain]] in the [[Royal Australian Navy]], and was actively involved in [[nuclear weapons testing]] on the [[Montebello Islands]] in 1952, as part of [[Operation Hurricane]]."[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article49028697 R.A.N. Ships For Atomic Tests Call At Onslow]" – ''[[The West Australian]]''. Published 28 April 1952. ===Far East and return to North America=== ''Half-Safe'''s Australian tour began in late October 1955 in Perth, where Carlin grew up, and included a tour of his old school, Guildford Grammar. The Carlins then went to [[Adelaide]], and subsequently progressed to [[Melbourne]], [[Sydney]], and [[Brisbane]]. ''Half-Safe'' was returned to Calcutta on a steamship in January 1956. However, Elinore, Carlin's wife, left the trip in Australia, having finally tired of the long travel and the constant seasickness she was experiencing. Carlin continued his journey alone, with the first leg consisting of a sea voyage from Calcutta to [[Akyab]], [[Burma]], across the [[Bay of Bengal]]. At Akyab, he was joined by Barry Hanley, another Australian. The two met on Burma's coast in late February 1956, and from there crossed the [[Arakan Yoma]] mountain ranges to the [[Irrawaddy River]], where the vehicle was bogged down in mud for two days. After extricating ''Half-Safe'' from the mire, the pair progressed to [[Rangoon]], arriving on 11 March."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=YjlVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hZUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3858,1810379&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en "Half Safe" in Rangoon After Adventurous Trip]" – ''[[The Age]]''. Published 12 March 1956. From Burma, ''Half-Safe'' was driven overland to [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]], and from there to [[Saigon]], on the coast of [[Indochina]]."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Zx8aAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bCUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5200,5113854&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en Amphibious Jeep at Halfway Mark on World Jaunt]" – ''[[The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|The Milwaukee Journal]]''. Published 8 June 1956. From there, Carlin and Hanley set out to sail from Indochina to Japan, passing through several ports and islands in the [[South China Sea]]. Upon his arrival in [[Hong Kong]] in early May 1956, Carlin was "mobbed by autograph-seeking girls", having been delayed on his voyage by engine trouble and headwinds in the South China Sea."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nW1jAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TnkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5552,892376&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en Carlin, Jeep Arrive in Hong Kong]" – ''[[Saskatoon StarPhoenix|Saskatoon Star-Phoenix]]''. Published 7 May 1956. He arrived in [[Kaohsiung]], [[Taiwan]], in early June, and from there travelled to [[Keelung]] on the northern tip of Taiwan, and [[Okinawa]], part of the [[United States Civil Administration of the Ryukyu Islands|American-administered Ryukyu Islands]]."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EjBkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6nsNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1810,1614612&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en 'Half Safe' Jeep Reaches Formosa On World Jaunt]" – ''[[The Calgary Herald]]''. Published 8 June 1956. Carlin and Hanley drove ashore at [[Kagoshima Prefecture]] at the southern tip of Japan in July 1956, and from there drove overland to [[Tokyo]].White, Sid (1956). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Z8IvAAAAIBAJ&sjid=akgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5000,2057908&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en Australian Traveler Takes Rest In Tokyo] – ''[[The Deseret News]]''. Published 10 October 1956. Hanley returned to Australia at this stage, while Carlin rested in Japan, again performing much-needed repairs. An American journalist for ''[[The Japan Times]]'', [[Boyé Lafayette De Mente|Boyé Lafayette de Mente]] (originally of [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]], [[Arizona]]), offered to accompany Carlin on the journey from Japan to [[Alaska]], departing in early 1957 for the first stage of the trip from Tokyo to [[Wakkanai, Hokkaidō|Wakkanai]], [[Hokkaidō]]. The pair left Tokyo on 1 May 1957 to great fanfare, cheered off from the [[Mainichi Newspapers|Mainichi]] and [[Yomiuri newspaper|Yomiuri Newspaper]] buildings. The craft sprang a leak while crossing the [[Tsugaru Strait]], separating the southern island of [[Honshu]] from Hokkaidō, and collided with submerged rocks near the port of [[Muroran, Hokkaidō|Muroran]].[http://www.4wdonline.com/reader-contributions/amphibious-jeep-half-safe-co-adventurer-connects-with-4wdonline-com.html Amphibious Jeep “Half-Safe” Co-Adventurer connects with 4WDOnline.com] – 4wdonline. Retrieved 3 October 2012. They finally reached Wakkanai on 12 June 1957, despite what de Mente later described as Carlin's aggression and "irascible character" during the trip."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=poBlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-okNAAAAIBAJ&pg=860,2397081&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en PAIR TRY TO DRIVE PACIFIC]" – ''The Sunday Sun''. Published 11 June 1957. [[File:BenCarlinAndBoyeDeMente-01.gif|thumb|left|200px|Carlin and his new travelling partner, [[Boyé Lafayette De Mente|Boyé de Mente]], departed from [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]], in May 1957.]] Carlin's aim was to travel directly from Wakkanai to [[Shemya]], a small island in the [[Near Islands]] group of the [[Semichi Islands]] chain, part of the [[Aleutian Islands]] running southwest of the Alaskan mainland. The craft was carrying enough fuel to last for approximately 21 days, but did not make contact within this time, causing the US Coast Guard's [[search and rescue]] station to be notified."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=An8KAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VksDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6989,226207&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en Can't Contact Two Men On Japan Jaunt]" – ''[[Daily Record (Washington)|Ellensburg Daily Record]]''. Published 4 July 1957. ''Half-Safe'' finally landed on Shemya on 8 July, with the pair having made an unexpected detour to visit the town of [[Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky|Petropavlovsk]] on the [[Kamchatka Peninsula]], at the time part of the [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Russian SFSR]]."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LPxXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8_YDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7042,1496076&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en Pair Cross Rough Sea In Amphibious Jeep]" – ''[[Spokane Daily Chronicle]]''. Published 8 July 1957. From Shemya, Carlin and de Mente sailed to [[Adak Island]], a distance of {{convert|350|mi|km}}, then a further {{convert|580|mi|km}} to [[Cold Bay, Alaska|Cold Bay]], and thence along the Aleutian island chain to the mainland town of [[Homer, Alaska|Homer]], arriving in late August."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eY4uAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5IgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2983,2063267&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en Continue Amphibious Jeep Trip]" – ''[[Tri-City Herald]]''. Published 17 July 1957."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4qFaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=g08DAAAAIBAJ&pg=3193,3977891&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en Pheenix Man, Australian Head for Homer, Alaska]" – ''[[Prescott Evening Courier]]''. Published 19 August 1957. Carlin and de Mente then drove ''Half-Safe'' overland to [[Anchorage, Alaska|Anchorage]], where de Mente flew home to Phoenix. He would go on to write ''Once a Fool: From Tokyo to Alaska by Amphibious Jeep'', a detailed account of his experiences with Carlin and ''Half-Safe'', as well as becoming a prolific author on topics relating to [[Mesoamerica]] and [[East Asia]], publishing over 100 books. Carlin subsequently drove solo to [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], arriving in early November 1957."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tP1XAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-vYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5459,1732443&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en Short Takes In The News]" – ''[[Spokane Daily Chronicle]]''. Published 8 November 1957. Whilst travelling the [[Alaska Highway]] in [[British Columbia]], he encountered the collapsed [[Peace River Suspension Bridge]]. While other motorists queued for a nearby ferry, Carlin simply drove ''Half-Safe'' into the river and across to the other side."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HmZkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=a3wNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1778,4973975&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en Jeep Used In World Circling Trip]" – ''[[The Calgary Herald]]''. Published 26 December 1957. Continuing on to [[San Francisco]], [[California]], where he met his wife for the first time in two years, Carlin then continued onwards through the United States and north to Canada. He arrived in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], on 10 May 1958,"[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=hWZkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aXwNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6091,2379061&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en Amphibious Jeep Finishes 10-Year Tour Of Globe]" – ''[[Calgary Herald]]''. Published 10 May 1958. and three days later arrived in Montreal, where he finally completed his ten-year journey."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WUswAAAAIBAJ&sjid=b6gFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5238,2288876&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en Amphibian Traveller Home After 10 Years]" – ''[[The Montreal Gazette]]''. Published 13 May 1958. He and ''Half-Safe'' had travelled {{convert|17780|km|mi}} by sea and {{convert|62744|km|mi}} by land over ten years, passing through 38 countries and over two oceans, with the entire trip costing him around $35,000."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iGZkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aXwNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5039,3280567&dq=ben-carlin&hl=en NEARS END OF JOURNEY.]" – ''[[The Calgary Herald]]''. Published 14 May 1958. ==Later life and legacy== {{Commons category|Ben and Elinore Carlin}} After the conclusion of the trip, ''Half-Safe'' remained in the United States, where it was occasionally exhibited by Carlin's friend George Calimer, who was a co-owner of the vehicle. Carlin remained in the country for a period, appearing on the lecture circuit, before returning to Perth, where he took up residence in [[Cottesloe, Western Australia|Cottesloe]]. Having divorced his second wife Elinore by December 1955, Carlin wed for a third time on 1 June 1963 in the United States, marrying Cynthia Henderson. Although the couple's marriage was short-lived, the union produced one daughter, Deirdre Scott Carlin, who was born in March 1964. Carlin died in Perth in March 1981, of a [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]], and was [[Cremation|cremated]] at [[Karrakatta Cemetery]]. His second wife, Elinore, who completed the first half of his journey alongside him, died in 1996 in New York City. Carlin left his share in ''Half-Safe'' to his old school, Guildford Grammar, as well as a sizeable endowment for the purposes of funding a scholarship. He had previously offered the craft to the [[Western Australian Maritime Museum]], which declined the offer due to a lack of exhibition space.{{harvnb|de Mente|2005|p=17}} The Guildford Grammar School Foundation subsequently purchased the other share in the vehicle, transferring it to the school's campus in [[Guildford, Western Australia|Guildford]], Western Australia. The school also posthumously published ''The Other Half of Half-Safe'', which detailed the second portion of Carlin's journey.Hunt, Bruce (2011). [https://archive.is/20121230122312/http://www.inmycommunity.com.au/news-and-views/local-news/Amphibious-jeep-is-stuff-of-navigation-dreams/7594699/ Amphibious jeep is stuff of navigation dreams] – In My Community. Published 23 June 2011. Retrieved 21 October 2012. In 1999, the craft was transported by truck across Australia to [[Corowa, New South Wales|Corowa]], [[New South Wales]], where it featured in an annual celebration on the [[Murray River]], along with 16 other amphibious vehicles from the Second World War. ''Half-Safe'' is currently exhibited in a specially-made glass enclosure at Guildford Grammar's main campus. Money from Carlin's estate was used to found the Charlotte Carlin Scholarship (named for his mother), awarded for "the proficiency of the English language with the avoidance of clichés". [[Guinness World Records]] recognises Carlin as having completed the "first and only circumnavigation by an amphibious vehicle".[http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/records-1/first-circumnavigation-by-amphibious-car/ First circumnavigation by amphibious car] – Guinness World Records. Retrieved 28 February 2013. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== {{refbegin|1}} * {{cite book| last = Bass| first = Gordon| title = The Last Great Australian Adventurer: Ben Carlin's epic journey around the world by amphibious Jeep| url = https://www.amazon.com.au/Last-Great-Australian-Adventurer-amphibious-ebook/dp/B06XNR2RPR/| year = 2017| publisher = Random House Australia | isbn = 9781925324990| ref = harv }} * {{cite book| last = Carlin| first = Ben| title = Half-Safe: Across the Atlantic by Jeep| year = 1955| publisher = Andrew Deutsch| isbn = 978-0-9598731-1-5| ref = harv| location = London }} * {{cite book| last = Carlin| first = Ben| title = The Other Half of Half-Safe: Around the World by Amphibious Jeep from Montreal Across the Atlantic, Europe, Asia, Australia, Japan and the Pacific to Canada and Back to Montreal| url = https://www.amazon.com/THE-OTHER-HALF-HALF-SAFE-Amphibious/dp/0959873112| year = 1989| publisher = Guildford Grammar School Foundation, Inc.| isbn = 0959873112| ref = harv }} * {{cite book| last = de Mente| first = Boyé| authorlink = Boyé Lafayette De Mente| title = Once a Fool: From Tokyo to Alaska by Amphibious Jeep| url = https://books.google.com/?id=_QSIUANtVa4C| year = 2005| publisher = Phoenix Books| isbn = 0914778048| ref = harv }} * {{cite book| last = Nestor| first = James| authorlink = James Nestor (writer) | title = Half-Safe: A Story of Love, Obsession, and History's Most Insane Around-the-world Adventure| url = https://www.atavist.com/stories/half-safe/| year = 2013| publisher = The Atavist| ref = harv| asin = B00AQZEFC8 }} {{refend}} == External links == * {{Find a Grave|166091378}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Carlin, Ben}} [[Category:1912 births]] [[Category:1981 deaths]] officers]] [[Category:Burials at Karrakatta Cemetery]] [[Category:Circumnavigators of the globe]] [[Category:Indian Army personnel of World War II]] [[Category:Maritime writers]] [[Category:Australian mining engineers]] [[Category:People educated at Guildford Grammar School]] [[Category:People from Northam, Western Australia]]

==Biogas== There is a high [[biogas]] potential in [[Turkey]].<ref name=TGBP>{{cite web|title=Assessment of actual framework conditions and potentials for Biogas investments in Turkey|url=http://biyogaz.web.tr/files/docs/dbfz_biogas-potential_analysis_turkey.pdf|publisher=Turkish-German biogas project}}</ref> More than eighty five million tons of animal waste produced annually could produce over 1.8 million tons of oil equivalent (toe) and with plant waste included the potential raises to over 5.3 million tons of oil equivalent (toe).<ref>{{cite web|title=Biogas Energy In Turkey|url=http://www.mondaq.com/x/312640/Renewables/Biogas+Energy+In+Turkey}}</ref> However, only 85 biogas facilities with 36 plants are currently in operation.<ref name=TGBP />
80 MW of landfill power is in operation while 78 MW is under construction.<ref>{{cite web|last1=OLGUN|first1=Prof. Dr. Hayati|title=STATUS OF BIOENERGY IN TURKEY|url=http://iet.jrc.ec.europa.eu/remea/sites/remea/files/files/documents/events/olgun.pdf|publisher=European Commission}}</ref>
==Biodiesel== A [[biodiesel]] plant is planned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avesenerji.com/wp-content/uploads/katalog-en.pdf}}</ref>
==Bioethanol== Sugar beets are the main source of [[bioethanol]] production in Turkey, followed by corn and wheat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefarmsite.com/reports/contents/TurkeySugar9May2014.pdf}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Turkey|Energy}} * [[Renewable energy in Turkey]] * [[Solar power in Turkey]] * [[Wind power in Turkey]] * [[Geothermal power in Turkey]] * [[Hydroelectricity in Turkey]] * [[List of renewable energy topics by country|Renewable energy by country]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Energy in Turkey]] [[Category:Biofuels]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox Comet | name=C/2013 V5 | discoverer=Oukaimeden Observatory
0.5-m [[reflecting telescope|reflector]] ([[List of observatory codes#J00-J99|J43]]) | discovery_date=12 November 2013 | epoch=20 September 2014 | perihelion=0.62539 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] (q) | eccentricity=0.99868 | period=several million years inbound (Barycentric solution for [[Epoch (astronomy)|epoch]] 1950)
~6000 [[Julian year (astronomy)|years]] outbound
(Barycentric solution for epoch 2050) | inclination=154.88° | last_p=28 September 2014 }} '''C/2013 V5''' (Oukaimeden) is a [[Retrograde motion|retrograde]] [[Oort cloud]] [[comet]] discovered on 12 November 2013 by Oukaimeden Observatory at an [[apparent magnitude]] of 19.4 using a {{convert|0.5|m|in|adj=on|sp=us}} [[reflecting telescope]]. From 5 May 2014 until 18 July 2014 it had an [[Elongation (astronomy)|elongation]] less than 30 degrees from the Sun. By late August 2014 it had brighten to [[apparent magnitude]] 8 making it a small telescope and high-end [[binoculars]] target for experienced observers. It crossed the [[celestial equator]] on 30 August 2014 becoming a [[southern hemisphere]] object. On 16 September 2014 the comet passed {{convert|0.480|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} from Earth. The comet peaked around magnitude 6.2 in mid-September 2014 but only had an [[Elongation (astronomy)|elongation]] of about 35 degrees from the Sun. On 20 September 2014 the comet was visible in [[STEREO|STEREO HI-1B]]. The comet came to [[Apsis|perihelion]] (closest approach to the Sun) on 28 September 2014 at a distance of {{convert|0.625|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} from the Sun. C/2013 V5 is dynamically new. It came from the [[Oort cloud]] with a loosely bound chaotic orbit that was easily perturbed by [[galactic tide]]s and [[List of nearest stars#Future and past|passing stars]]. Before entering the planetary region ([[Epoch (astronomy)|epoch]] 1950), C/2013 V5 had an orbital period of several million years. After leaving the planetary region (epoch 2050), it will have an orbital period of about 6000 years. == References == {{reflist | refs = {{cite web |date=2013-11-15 |title=MPEC 2013-V95 : COMET C/2013 V5 (OUKAIMEDEN) |publisher=[[IAU Minor Planet Center]] |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K13/K13V95.html |accessdate=2013-05-05}} (CK13V050) {{cite web |date=12 May 2014 |title=MPEC 2014-J58: Observations and Orbits of Comets |publisher=IAU Minor Planet Center |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K14/K14JA2.html |accessdate=2014-06-15}} {{cite web |title = Elements and Ephemeris for C/2013 V5 (Oukaimeden) |publisher = IAU Minor Planet Center |url = http://scully.cfa.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/returnprepeph.cgi?d=c&o=CK13V050 |accessdate = 2014-06-15 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{cite web |date=2014-05-11 |title=C/2013 V5 ( Oukaimeden ) |publisher=Seiichi Yoshida's Comet Catalog |author=Seiichi Yoshida |url=http://www.aerith.net/comet/catalog/2013V5/2013V5.html |accessdate=2013-06-15}} {{cite web |date=2014-08-31 |title=Weekly Information about Bright Comets (2014 Aug. 23: South) |first=Seiichi |last=Yoshida |publisher=aerith.net |url=http://www.aerith.net/comet/weekly/20140823s.html |accessdate=2014-10-21}} {{cite web |date=2014-09-20 |title=Weekly Information about Bright Comets (2014 Sept. 20: South) |first=Seiichi |last=Yoshida |publisher=aerith.net |url=http://www.aerith.net/comet/weekly/20140920s.html |accessdate=2014-10-21}} {{cite web |type=last observation: 2014-04-13; [[Observation arc|arc]]: 152 days |title=JPL Close-Approach Data: C/2013 V5 (Oukaimeden) |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2013V5;cad=1#cad |accessdate=2014-06-15}} {{cite web |author=[[JPL Horizons On-Line Ephemeris System|Horizons]] output |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/horizons.cgi?find_body=1&body_group=sb&sstr=2013V5 |title=Barycentric Osculating Orbital Elements for Comet C/2013 V5 (Oukaimeden) |accessdate=2014-06-15}} (Solution using the Solar System [[Center of mass#Barycenter in astrophysics and astronomy|Barycenter]] and [[Barycentric coordinates (astronomy)|barycentric coordinates]]. Select Ephemeris Type:Elements and Center:@0) {{cite web |date=2014-09-22 |title=Comet C/2013 V5 Oukaimeden is in the @NASA STEREO HI-1B images |author=Karl Battams |url=https://twitter.com/SungrazerComets/status/514421784184377344 |accessdate=2014-09-23}} }} == External links == *[http://www.smph.cz/datas/users/1/1407791576_1d41d4_1.png Activity level and perihelion distance] (Bortle survival limit Jakub Cerny 11 August 2014) *[http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_v5_2014_08_31dp.jpg C/2013 V5 Oukaimeden wide-field] (Damian Peach 31 August 2014) *[https://www.flickr.com/photos/47833278@N02/14965966275/ C/2013 V5 map for Aug 21 – Sept 5] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20150907220340/http://gloria.fzu.cz/en/news/oukaimeden_decay Did we catch disintegration of comet Oukaimeden?] (FRAM) *[http://www.smph.cz/datas/users/1/1411573977_94d535_1.png (C/2013 V5 magnitude)] {{Comets}} {{2014 in space}} [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 2013|20131112]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 2014|20140916]] [[Category:Comets in 2013|20131112]] [[Category:Comets in 2014|20140928]] [[Category:Oort cloud]] {{comet-stub}}

{{Other uses|Charles Bowden (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox person |name = Charles Bowden |image = Charles_Bowden.png |image_size = 250px |alt = |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date|1945|07|20}} |birth_place = [[Joliet, Illinois|Joliet]], [[Illinois]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = {{death date and age|2014|08|30|1945|07|20}} |death_place = [[Las Cruces, New Mexico|Las Cruces]], [[New Mexico]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_cause = |body_discovered = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> |education = |occupation = Writer, journalist |known_for = |notable_works = |awards = [[Lannan Literary Awards|Lannan Literary Award for Nonfiction]] |signature = |signature_alt = |signature_size = |website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''Charles Clyde Bowden''' (July 20, 1945 – August 30, 2014) was an American non-fiction author, journalist and essayist based in [[Las Cruces, New Mexico|Las Cruces]], [[New Mexico]].<ref name="Diaz">{{Cite web|url=http://www.lannan.org/bios/charles-bowden|title=Charles Bowden - Lannan Foundation|last=Diaz|first=Alex|website=www.lannan.org|access-date=2016-04-08}}</ref>
==Background== He attended the [[University of Arizona]] and then the [[University of Wisconsin System|University of Wisconsin]], where he obtained his master's degree in American intellectual history; while there he walked out as he was defending his dissertation for his doctorate, annoyed by the questions asked him by the review committee.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/04/books/charles-bowden-lyrical-writer-dies-at-69.html|title=Charles Bowden, Author With Unblinking Eye on Southwest, Dies at 69|last=Yardley|first=William|date=2014-09-03|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-04-08}}</ref> He was a writer for the ''[[Tucson Citizen]]'' and often wrote about the [[Southwestern United States|American Southwest]]. He was a contributing editor of ''[[GQ]]'' and ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'' magazine,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://motherjones.com/authors/charles-bowden|title=Charles Bowden|website=motherjones|access-date=2016-04-08}}</ref> and wrote for other periodicals including ''[[Harper's Magazine]]'', ''[[The New York Times Book Review]]'', ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'', ''[[High Country News]]'', and ''[[Aperture (magazine)|Aperture]]''.
Bowden was the winner of the 1996 [[Lannan Literary Awards|Lannan Literary Award for Nonfiction]],<ref name="Diaz"/> and a 2010 award from [[United States Artists]].<ref>[http://www.unitedstatesartists.org/Public2/Home/index.cfm United States Artists Official Website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101110032536/http://www.unitedstatesartists.org/Public2/Home/index.cfm |date=November 10, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-et-jc-charles-bowden-dies-20140831-story.html|title=Charles Bowden dies at 69; author known for writing on border issues|website=latimes.com|access-date=2016-04-08}}</ref> He grew up in [[Chicago]] but lived most of his life in [[Tucson, Arizona|Tucson]], [[Arizona]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Grant|first1=Richard|title=A Sense of Chuck|url=http://aeon.co/magazine/culture/charles-bowden-and-the-refuge-of-the-senses/|website=[[Aeon (digital magazine)]]|accessdate=6 April 2015}}</ref> He was known for his writings on the situation at the [[Mexico–United States border|US–Mexico border]] and wrote often about the effects of the [[War on Drugs]] on the lives of the people in that region.<ref name=":0" />
He died in Las Cruces, New Mexico, on August 30, 2014, after a brief illness. He was survived by his son and two siblings.<ref name=":0" />
==Selected works== * ''The Impact of Energy Development on Water Resources in Arid Lands: Literature Review and Annotated Bibliography'' (Tucson: University of Arizona, Office of Arid Lands Studies, 1975) * ''Killing the Hidden Waters'' (Austin: University of Texas Press, 1977) * ''Street Signs Chicago: Neighborhood and Other Illusions of Big City Life'' / by Charles Bowden and Lew Kreinberg; photographs by Richard Younker; foreword by William Appleman Williams (Chicago, IL: Chicago Review Press, 1981) * ''Blue Desert'' (Tucson: University of Arizona Press, 1986) * ''Frog Mountain Blues'' photographs by Jack W. Dykinga. (Tucson: University of Arizona Press, 1987) * ''Trust Me: [[Charles Keating]] and the Missing Billions'' (1988) with Michael Binstein * ''Mezcal'' (Tucson: University of Arizona Press, 1988) * ''Red Line'' (New York: Norton, 1989) * ''Desierto: Memories of the Future'' (1991) * ''The Sonoran Desert'' / photographs by Jack W. Dykinga; text by Charles Bowden. (New York: H. N. Abrams, 1992) * ''The Secret Forest'' / text by Charles Bowden; photographs by Jack W. Dykinga; introduction by Paul S. Martin (Albuquerque: University of New Mexico Press, 1993) * ''Seasons of the Coyote: the Legend and Lore of an American Icon'' / essays by Charles Bowden et al. (San Francisco, CA: HarperCollins West, 1994) * ''Frog Mountain Blues'' ; photographs by Jack W. Dykinga; with a new afterword by the author (Tucson: University of Arizona Press, 1994) * ''Blood Orchid: An Unnatural History of America'' (1995) * ''Chihuahua: Pictures From the Edge'' / photographs by Virgil Hancock; essay by Charles Bowden (Albuquerque: University of New Mexico Press, 1996) * ''Stone Canyons of the Colorado Plateau'' / photographs by Jack W. Dykinga; text by Charles Bowden (New York: Abrams, 1996) * ''The Sierra Pinacate'' / Julian D. Hayden; photographs by Jack Dykinga; with essays by Charles Bowden & Bernard L. Fontana (Tucson: University of Arizona Press, 1998) * ''Juárez: The Laboratory of our Future'', preface by [[Noam Chomsky]]; afterword by [[Eduardo Galeano]] (1998) * ''Torch Song'' (essay) 1999 * ''Paul Dickerson, 1961-1997'' (essay by Charles Bowden; New York: American Fine Art Co., 2000) * ''Eugene Richards'' (New York, NY: Phaidon, 2001) * ''Down by the River: Drugs, Money, Murder, and Family'' (2002) * ''Blues for Cannibals'' (2002) * ''Killing the Hidden Waters'' [with a new introduction by the author] (Austin: University of Texas Press, 2003) * ''A Shadow in the City : Confessions of an Undercover Drug Warrior'' (2005) * ''Inferno'' (photographs by Michael P. Berman; Austin, TX: University of Texas Press, 2006)(winner of the [[Border Regional Library Association|Border Regional Library Association's]] Southwest Book Award) * Introduction. ''Sometimes a Great Notion'', by Ken Kesey, Penguin Books, 2006, pp. xiii-xix. * ''Exodus/Éxodo'' (text by Charles Bowden, photographs by Julián Cardona) (2008) * ''Kill the Messenger: How the CIA's Crack-Cocaine Controversy Destroyed Journalist Gary Webb'' by Nick Schou; preface by Charles Bowden (2006) * ''Some of the Dead are Still Breathing: Living in the Future'' (2009) * ''Murder City: Ciudad Juárez and the Global Economy's New Killing Fields'' (2010) * ''Dreamland: The Way Out of Juárez'' (2010); with illustrations by Alice Leora Briggs * ''El Sicario: The Autobiography of a Mexican Assassin'' (2011) by Molly Molloy (Editor), Charles Bowden (Editor) * ''Dead When I Got Here: Asylum from the madness'' (2014); Executive Producer of Documentary in collaboration with Director/Producer Mark Aitken - [http://deadwhenigothere.org deadwhenigothere.org]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
== Archival sources == * [http://www.thewittliffcollections.txstate.edu/research/a-z/bowden.html The Charles Bowden Papers] 1947-2007 (50 linear feet) are housed at the Wittliff Collections, Texas State University in San Marcos.

An excerpt from ''Blues for Cannibals'' * [http://www.buzzflash.com/interviews/06/03/int06008.html An Interview with Charles Bowden] * [https://archive.is/20130118154616/http://byliner.com/writers/charles-bowden/ Charles Bowden articles at Byliner] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060615161612/http://marketplace.publicradio.org/features/undocumented_war/ An audio interview with Charles Bowden] - From American Public Media's ''Marketplace'' * {{worldcat id|id=lccn-n81-90470}} * [http://www.democracynow.org/2010/3/16/charles_bowden_on_the_war_next Charles Bowden on "The War Next Door"] - video by ''[[Democracy Now!]]'' * [http://www.democracynow.org/2010/4/14/charles_bowden_murder_city_ciudad_jurez Charles Bowden on “Murder City: Ciudad Juárez and the Global Economy’s New Killing Fields”] - A live interview with Charles Bowden on ''[[Democracy Now!]]'' April 14, 2010 * [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4730103 NPR interview with Bowden about "Shadow in the City"] on NPR's ''[[Day to Day]]'' July 5, 2005 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100806061447/http://www.hcn.org/issues/42.4/the-war-next-door/article_view?b_start%3Aint=0&-C= "Charles Bowden on The War Next Door"], ''High Country News'', March 1, 2010 * {{cite journal |last=Bowden |first=Charles |title=Arkansas Delta, 40 Years Later |journal=National Geographic |url=http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2012/11/arkansas-delta/bowden-text |date=November 2012 |volume=222 |issue=5 |pages=125–139 |accessdate=2 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6H6hsLZCZ?url=http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2012/11/arkansas-delta/bowden-text |archivedate=3 June 2013 |df= }} * [https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/sep/07/charles-bowden Obituary] in [[The Guardian]] September 8, 2014

revision.comment: /* Shape */ deleted distracting diversion about a slope
revision.text:
[[File:Terrestrial_rainbow.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Dewbow on the ground]] [[File:Dewbow on a spiderweb.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Dewbow on a spiderweb]]
A '''dewbow''' is an [[optical effect]], similar to a [[rainbow]], where [[dew]]drops instead of rain droplets reflect and disperse sunlight.<ref name="Boyle">{{cite web|url=http://www.atoptics.co.uk/rainbows/dewbow.htm|title=Dewbow|last=Boyle|first=Kevin |accessdate=2009-07-19}}</ref><ref name="Summary of Dewbows">{{cite book|last=Dunlop|first=Storm|title=Weather|publisher=Collins|year=2009|pages=151|isbn=978-0-00-784141-7}}</ref>
==Occurrence== Dewbows can be seen on fields covered with dew, when the sun shines. Dew forms outdoors in the early morning after a clear night, when the surface temperature drops below the [[dew point]]. It forms most easily on surfaces that are isolated from conducted heat from deep ground, such as grass, leaves, and spider webs. Dew bows will be clearest on fields littered with cobwebs, as may occur in autumn. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weatherscapes.com/album.php?cat=optics&subcat=dew_bow|title=Dew bow |last=Edens|first=Harald |accessdate=2009-07-19}}</ref>
==Shape== A ''rainbow'' is perceived as a circle in the sky; and its contributing light rays form a cone. In contrast, a ''dewbow'' is perceived as the intersection of that cone and the ground. If the ground is flat and horizontal, and the sun is low in the sky, the dew bow is a [[hyperbola]]. Theoretically, when the sun is high, the intersection might be another [[conic section]], like a [[parabola]] or an [[ellipse]].<ref name="Boyle"/> However, dew usually evaporates before the sun is high. Nonetheless, an elliptical dew bow was captured on camera, when at night the full moon, high in the sky, illuminated a field loaded with dew.<ref name="Großmann">{{cite web|url=https://atoptics.wordpress.com/author/atoptics/page/10/|title=Dew bow|last=Großmann|first=Michael |accessdate=2018-05-25}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Fogbow]] *[[Moonbow]]
==References== {{reflist|1}}
[[Category:Atmospheric optical phenomena]] [[Category:Atmospheric sciences]] [[Category:Precipitation]]
