revision.text:
{{short description|A coupled ocean-atmosphere phenomenon that is the counterpart of El Niño}} {{for|the ship|Niña}} [[File:Sea Surface Temperature - November 2007.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Sea surface skin temperature anomalies in November 2007, showing La Niña conditions]]
'''La Niña''' ({{IPAc-en|l|ɑː|ˈ|n|iː|n|j|ə|}}, {{IPA-es|la ˈniɲa}}) is a coupled ocean-atmosphere phenomenon that is the counterpart of [[El Niño]] as part of the broader [[El Niño–Southern Oscillation]] [[climate pattern]]. The name La Niña originates from [[Spanish language|Spanish]], meaning "the little girl", analogous to El Niño meaning "the little boy". It has also in the past been called ''anti-El Niño'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/ninonina.html|title=What are El Nino and La Nina?|date=|website=oceanservice.noaa.gov|language=EN-US|access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref> and El Viejo (meaning "the old man").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pmel.noaa.gov/tao/elnino/la-nina-story.html|title=What is La Niña?|author=Tropical Atmosphere Ocean project|date=2008-03-24|accessdate=2009-07-17|publisher=Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory}}</ref> During a period of La Niña, the [[sea surface temperature]] across the equatorial Eastern Central [[Pacific Ocean]] will be lower than normal by 3 to 5 °C. In the United States, an ''appearance'' of La Niña persists for at least five months. It has extensive effects on the weather in [[North America]], even affecting the [[Atlantic hurricane|Atlantic]] and [[Pacific hurricane]] seasons.
==Definition== La Niña is the positive phase of the [[El Niño–Southern Oscillation]] and is associated with cooler-than-average sea surface temperatures in the central and eastern tropical Pacific Ocean.<ref>{{cite web|title=Australian Climate Influences: La Niña|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/watl/about-weather-and-climate/australian-climate-influences.shtml|publisher=Australian Bureau of Meteorology|accessdate=4 April 2016}}</ref> However, each country and island nation has a different threshold for what constitutes a La Niña event, which is tailored to their specific interests.<ref name="December 2014 EU">{{cite web|date=4 December 2014|title=December's ENSO Update: Close, but no cigar|archivedate=3 April 2016|author1=Becker, Emily|url=https://www.climate.gov/news-features/blogs/enso/decembers-enso-update-close-no-cigar|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6gVGgNf0S?url=https://www.climate.gov/news-features/blogs/enso/decembers-enso-update-close-no-cigar|website=ENSO Blog}}</ref> For example, the Australian [[Bureau of Meteorology]] looks at the trade winds, SOI, weather models and sea surface temperatures in the Niño 3 and 3.4 regions before declaring that a La Niña event has started.<ref>{{cite web|title=ENSO Tracker: About ENSO and the Tracker|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/enso/tracker/#tabs=About-ENSO-and-the-Tracker|publisher=Australian Bureau of Meteorology|accessdate=April 4, 2016}}</ref> However, the [[Japan Meteorological Agency]] declares that a La Niña event has started when the average five-month sea surface temperature deviation for the NINO.3 region is more than {{convert|0.5|C-change}} cooler for 6 consecutive months or longer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Historical El Niño and La Niña Events|accessdate=April 4, 2016|url=http://ds.data.jma.go.jp/tcc/tcc/products/elnino/ensoevents.html|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency}}</ref>
==Occurrences== <center> <timeline> ImageSize = width:800 height:70 PlotArea = left:50 bottom:20 width:700 height:40 Period = from:1900 till:2018 DateFormat = yyyy TimeAxis = orientation:horizontal ScaleMajor = unit:year increment:5 start:1900 PlotData = bar:laniña width:30 color:blue mark:(line,white) from:1903 till:1904 from:1906 till:1907 from:1909 till:1911 from:1916 till:1918 from:1924 till:1925 from:1928 till:1930 from:1938 till:1939 from:1942 till:1943 from:1949 till:1951 from:1954 till:1957 from:1964 till:1965 from:1967 till:1968 from:1970 till:1972 from:1973 till:1974 from:1974 till:1976 from:1984 till:1985 from:1988 till:1989 from:1995 till:1996 from:1998 till:2001 from:2005 till:2006 from:2007 till:2008 from:2008 till:2009 from:2010 till:2012 from:2016 till:2017 from:2017 till:2018 </timeline> A timeline of all La Niña episodes between 1900 and 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cpc.noaa.gov/products/analysis_monitoring/ensostuff/ensoyears.shtml |title= Cold and warm episodes by season |accessdate=12 January 2011 |publisher=Climate Prediction Center NOAA |cite= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/enso/lnlist/index.shtml |title= La Niña – Detailed Australian Analysis |accessdate=3 April 2016 |publisher=Australian Bureau of Meteorology}}</ref> </center>
There was a relatively strong La Niña episode during 1988–1989. La Niña also formed in late 1983,<ref name="La Niña and Winter Weather"/> in 1995, and a protracted La Niña event that lasted from mid-1998 through early 2001. This was followed by a neutral period between 2001 and 2002. The La Niña which developed in mid-2007, and lasted until almost 2009, was a moderate one. The strength of La Niña made the [[2008 Atlantic hurricane season]] one of the five most active since 1944; sixteen named storms had winds of at least {{convert|39|mi/h|km/h}}, eight of which became {{convert|74|mi/h|km/h|adj=mid}} or greater hurricanes.<ref name="Sullivan10">{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-05-06/el-nino-warming-will-fade-out-by-june-u-s-says-update1-.html|title=El Niño Warning Will Fade Out by June, U.S. Says (Update 1)|date=2010-05-06|accessdate=2010-05-31|author=Brian K. Sullivan|publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek}}</ref>
A new La Niña episode developed quite quickly in the eastern and central tropical Pacific in mid-2010,<ref name="ReferenceA"/> and lasted until early 2011.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web | url=http://www.cpc.noaa.gov/products/analysis_monitoring/enso_advisory/ensodisc.html | title=ENSO Diagnostic Discussion | work=NOAA's Climate Prediction Center | accessdate=10 January 2011}}</ref> It intensified again in mid-2011 and lasted until early 2012.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.noaanews.noaa.gov/stories2011/20110908_lanina.html | title=La Niña is back | work=NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center | date=8 September 2011 | accessdate=10 December 2011}}</ref> This La Niña, combined with record-high ocean temperatures in the north-eastern [[Indian Ocean]], was a large factor in the [[2010–2011 Queensland floods]],<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/weather/hi/news/newsid_9340000/9340513.stm | work=BBC News | title=Why is Queensland flooded? | date=13 January 2011}}</ref> and the quartet of recent heavy snowstorms in North America starting with the [[December 2010 North American blizzard]]. The same La Niña event was also a likely cause of a series of tornadoes of above-average severity that struck the Midwestern and Southern United States in the spring of 2011, and drought conditions in the South Central states including Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.physorg.com/news/2011-04-tornadoes-climate.html | title=Tornadoes whipped up by wind, not climate: officials | publisher=www.physorg.com | accessdate=30 April 2011}}</ref> Meanwhile, a series of major storms caused extensive flooding in California in December 2010, with seven consecutive days of non-stop rainfall, leading to one of the wettest Decembers in over 120 years of records. This is in contrast to the drier-than-normal conditions typically associated with La Niña in California, especially in the south.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnrfc.noaa.gov/storm_summaries/dec2010storms.php |title= Heavy Precipitation Event California and Nevada December 16 – 23, 2010 |accessdate=8 November 2014 |publisher=California Nevada River Forecast Center }}</ref>
In 2011, on a global scale, La Niña events helped keep the average global temperature below recent trends. As a result, 2011 tied with 1997 for the eleventh-warmest year on record. It was the second-coolest year of the 21st century to date, and tied with the second-warmest year of the 20th century. A relatively strong phase of La Niña opened the year, dissipated in the spring before re-emerging in October and lasted through the end of the year. When compared to previous La Niña years, the 2011 global surface temperature was the warmest observed. The 2011 globally-averaged precipitation over land was the second-wettest year on record, behind 2010. Precipitation varied greatly across the globe. This La Niña contributed to severe drought in [[East Africa]] and to Australia's third-wettest year in its 112-year period of records.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.noaanews.noaa.gov/stories2012/20120119_global_stats.html |title= NOAA: 2011 a year of climate extremes in the United States |accessdate=22 January 2012 |publisher=Climate Prediction Center NOAA }}</ref>
La Niñas occurred in 1904, 1908, 1910, 1916, 1924, 1928, 1938, 1949–51,<ref>{{cite web|title=La Nina Years|publisher=The Noaa News|url=http://www.noaanews.noaa.gov/stories/s300c.htm|accessdate=Apr 20, 2016}}</ref> 1954–56, 1964, 1970–72, 1973–76, 1983–85,<ref name="La Niña and Winter Weather">{{cite report|title=La Niña and Winter Weather|publisher=NOAA|url=http://www.nws.noaa.gov/om/winter/la_nina-q-a.shtml|accessdate=March 14, 2014}}</ref> 1988–89, 1995–96, 1998–2001, 2007–08, 2008–09, 2010–12, 2016–17 and 2017-18.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://www.cpc.noaa.gov/products/analysis_monitoring/ensostuff/ensoyears.shtml |title=Climate Prediction Center – Monitoring & Data: ENSO Impacts on the U.S. – Previous Events |website=Cpc.noaa.gov |date=2015-11-04 |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.publicaffairs.noaa.gov/lanina.html |title=La Niña Information |accessdate= 2010-05-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = Sutherland | first = Scott | title = La Niña calls it quits. Is El Niño paying us a return visit? | url = https://www.theweathernetwork.com/us/news/articles/la-nina-calls-it-quits-is-el-nino-paying-us-a-return-visit/79424 | work = [[The Weather Network]] | date = February 16, 2017 | accessdate = February 17, 2017}}</ref>
==Impacts on the global climate== La Niña impacts the global climate and disrupts normal weather patterns, which as a result can lead to intense storms in some places and droughts in others.<ref name="NIWA El Niño/La Niña">{{cite web|title=El Niño and La Niña|url=https://www.niwa.co.nz/climate/information-and-resources/elnino|publisher=New Zealand's National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6gg0KMM8L?url=https://www.niwa.co.nz/climate/information-and-resources/elnino|archivedate=11 April 2016|deadurl=no|accessdate=11 April 2016}}</ref>
==Regional impacts== Observations of La Niña events since 1950, show that impacts associated with La Niña events depend on what season it is.<ref name="Cascade">{{cite web|deadurl=no|date=19 May 2014|title=How ENSO leads to a cascade of global impacts|author1=Barnston, Anthony|website=ENSO Blog|url=https://www.climate.gov/news-features/blogs/enso/united-states-el-ni%C3%B1o-impacts-0|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6hHtGSj2e?url=https://www.climate.gov/news-features/blogs/enso/united-states-el-ni%C3%B1o-impacts-0|archivedate=5 May 2016}}</ref> However, while certain events and impacts are expected to occur during events, it is not certain or guaranteed that they will occur.<ref name="Cascade"/>
===Africa=== [[File:Oxfam East Africa - A family gathers sticks and branches for firewood.jpg|thumb|Between 50,000 and 100,000 people died during the [[2011 Horn of Africa drought]].<ref>"[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-16606021 Slow response to East Africa famine 'cost 'lives']". BBC News. January 18, 2012.</ref>]] La Niña results in wetter-than-normal conditions in Southern Africa from December to February, and drier-than-normal conditions over equatorial East Africa over the same period.<ref>[http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/WO1010/S00173/la-nina-weather-likely-to-last-for-months.htm La Niña Weather Likely To Last For Months | Scoop News]. Scoop.co.nz (2010-10-12). Retrieved 2013-06-15.</ref>
===Asia=== During La Niña years, the formation of tropical cyclones, along with the subtropical ridge position, shifts westward across the western Pacific Ocean, which increases the landfall threat to [[China]].<ref name="China">M. C. Wu, W. L. Chang, and W. M. Leung (2003). [http://ams.allenpress.com/perlserv/?request=get-document&doi=10.1175%2F1520-0442(2004)017%3C1419:IOENOE%3E2.0.CO%3B2 Impacts of El Niño–Southern Oscillation Events on Tropical Cyclone Landfalling Activity in the Western North Pacific.] Journal of Climate: pp. 1419–1428. Retrieved 2007-02-11.</ref> In March 2008, La Niña caused a drop in sea surface temperatures over Southeast Asia by 2 °C. It also caused heavy rains over [[Malaysia]], the [[Philippines]], and [[Indonesia]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Lynda |last=Hong |title=Recent heavy rain not caused by global warming |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/334735/1/.html |work=Channel NewsAsia |date=2008-03-13 |accessdate=2008-06-22}}</ref>
===North America=== [[File:La Nina regional impacts.gif|thumb|256px|Regional impacts of La Niña.]] La Niña causes mostly the opposite effects of El Niño, above-average [[precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]] across the northern Midwest, the northern Rockies, Northern California, and the Pacific Northwest's southern and eastern regions. Meanwhile, precipitation in the southwestern and southeastern states, as well as Southern California, is below average.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cpc.noaa.gov/products/analysis_monitoring/enso_advisory/ensodisc.html |title=ENSO Diagnostic Discussion |work=Climate Prediction Center |date=2008-06-05}}</ref> This also allows for the development of many stronger-than-average hurricanes in the Atlantic and fewer in the Pacific.
The [[Synoptic scale meteorology|synoptic]] condition for [[Tehuantepecer]] winds is associated with [[high-pressure system]] forming in [[Sierra Madre de Oaxaca|Sierra Madre]] of Mexico in the wake of an advancing cold front, which causes winds to accelerate through the [[Isthmus of Tehuantepec]]. Tehuantepecers primarily occur during the cold season months for the region in the wake of cold fronts, between October and February, with a summer maximum in July caused by the westward extension of the Azores-Bermuda high pressure system. Wind magnitude is weaker during La Niña years than [[El Niño]] years, due to the less frequent cold frontal incursions during La Niña winters,<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Rosario Romero-Centeno |author2=Jorge Zavala-Hidalgo |author3=Artemio Gallegos |author4=James J. O’Brien |title=Isthmus of Tehuantepec wind climatology and ENSO signal|journal=Journal of Climate|volume=16|number=15|pages=2628–2639|date=August 2003|doi=10.1175/1520-0442(2003)016<2628:iotwca>2.0.co;2|bibcode = 2003JCli...16.2628R }}</ref> with its effects can last from a few hours to six days.<ref name="MWL1971">{{cite journal|journal=Mariners Weather Log|author=Paul A. Arnerich|title=Tehuantepecer Winds of the West Coast of Mexico|pages=63–67|volume=15|number=2|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]}}</ref> Between 1942 and 1957, La Niña had an impact that caused isotope changes in the plants of Baja California.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Martínez-Ballesté|first=Andrea|last2=Ezcurra|first2=Exequiel|date=2018|title=Reconstruction of past climatic events using oxygen isotopes in Washingtonia robusta growing in three anthropic oases in Baja California|url=http://boletinsgm.igeolcu.unam.mx/bsgm/vols/epoca04/7001/%285%29Martinez.pdf|journal=Boletín de la Sociedad Geológica Mexicana|volume=70 |issue=1|pages=79–94|via=}}</ref>
In Canada, La Niña will, in general, cause a cooler, snowier winter, such as the near-record-breaking amounts of snow recorded in La Niña winter of 2007/2008 in Eastern Canada.<ref>{{cite web|title=3. A Never-Ending Winter |date=2008-12-29 |work=Canada's Top Ten Weather Stories for 2008 |publisher=Environment Canada |url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/doc/smc-msc/2008/s3_eng.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807170704/http://www.ec.gc.ca/doc/smc-msc/2008/s3_eng.html |archivedate=7 August 2011 }}</ref><ref name="cpc.noaa.gov">[https://web.archive.org/web/20050515171707/http://www.cpc.noaa.gov/products/analysis_monitoring/lanina/enso_evolution-status-fcsts-web.pdf]</ref>
===South America=== During a time of La Niña, drought plagues the coastal regions of Peru and Chile.<ref name="GLOBE">{{cite web |url=http://classic.globe.gov/fsl/html/templ.cgi?butler_lanina&lang=en |title=La Niña follows El Niño, the GLOBE El Niño Experiment continues |accessdate=2010-05-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015125212/http://classic.globe.gov/fsl/html/templ.cgi?butler_lanina&lang=en |archivedate=15 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> From December to February, northern Brazil is wetter than normal.<ref name=GLOBE/> La Niña causes higher than normal rainfall in the central Andes, which in turn causes catastrophic flooding on the Llanos de Mojos of Beni Department, Bolivia. Such flooding is documented from 1853, 1865, 1872, 1873, 1886, 1895, 1896, 1907, 1921, 1928, 1929 and 1931.<ref>Gary Van Valen, ''Indigenous Agency in the Amazon''(Tucson: University of Arizona Press, 2013), 10.</ref>
== Diversity == [[File:Enso-index-map.png|thumb|right|200 px|Map showing Niño3.4 and other index regions]] The traditional La Niña, also called Eastern Pacific (EP) La Niña,<ref name="Yu2009">{{cite journal|journal=J. Climate|author1=Kao, Hsun-Ying |author2=Jin-Yi Yu|title=Contrasting Eastern-Pacific and Central-Pacific Types of ENSO|volume=22|pages=615–632|year=2009|doi=10.1175/2008JCLI2309.1|issue=3|bibcode = 2009JCli...22..615K|url=http://www.ess.uci.edu/~yu/PDF/Kao+Yu.2OSC.JCL.2009.pdf}}</ref> involves temperature anomalies in the Eastern Pacific. However, in the last two decades, nontraditional La Niña were observed, in which the usual place of the temperature anomaly (Niño 1 and 2) is not affected, but an anomaly arises in the central Pacific (Niño 3.4).<ref name="Larkin2007">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1029/2005GL022738| title = On the definition of El Niño and associated seasonal average U.S. Weather anomalies| year = 2005| last1 = Larkin | first1 = N. K.| journal = Geophysical Research Letters| volume = 32| issue = 13| pages = L13705| last2 = Harrison | first2 = D. E.| bibcode=2005GeoRL..3213705L}}</ref> The phenomenon is called Central Pacific (CP) La Niña,<ref name="Yu2009"/> "dateline" La Niña (because the anomaly arises near the [[international dateline|dateline]]), or La Niña "Modoki" (Modoki is [[Japanese language|Japanese]] for "similar, but different").<ref name="LNM">{{cite journal |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs11434-012-5423-5 |title=Different types of La Niña events and different responses of the tropical atmosphere |journal=Chinese Science Bulletin |volume=58 |issue=3 |pages=406–415 |year=2012 |doi= 10.1007/s11434-012-5423-5 |author1=Yuan Yuan |author2=HongMing Yan|bibcode=2013ChSBu..58..406Y }}</ref><ref name="LNModoki">{{cite journal |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2009GL037885/abstract |title=La Niña Modoki impacts Australia autumn rainfall variability |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |volume=36 |issue=12 |year=2009 |doi= 10.1029/2009GL037885 |issn=0094-8276 |last1=Cai |first1=W. |last2=Cowan |first2=T. |bibcode=2009GeoRL..3612805C}}</ref> There are flavors of ENSO additional to EP and CP types and some scientists argue that ENSO exists as a continuum often with hybrid types.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Johnson |first=Nathaniel C. |title=How Many ENSO Flavors Can We Distinguish? |journal=J. Climate |volume=26 |issue=13 |pages=4816–27 |year=2013 |doi=10.1175/JCLI-D-12-00649.1 |bibcode=2013JCli...26.4816J}}</ref>
The effects of the CP La Niña are different from those of the traditional EP La Niña—e.g., the recently discovered La Niña leads to a rainfall increase over [[North West Australia|northwestern Australia]] and northern [[Murray-Darling basin]], rather than over the east as in a conventional La Niña.<ref name="LNModoki"/> Also, La Niña Modoki increases the frequency of cyclonic storms over [[Bay of Bengal]], but decreases the occurrence of severe storms in the [[Indian Ocean]] overall, with the [[Arabian Sea]] becoming severely non-conductive to tropical cyclone formation.<ref name="CPC ENSO">{{cite web | author = M R Ramesh Kumar | publisher = Society for Environmental Communications | title = El Nino, La Nina and the Indian sub-continent | url = http://www.downtoearth.org.in/content/el-nino-la-nina-and-indian-sub-continent | date = 2014-04-23 | accessdate = 2014-07-25}}</ref><ref name="Indian LMN">{{cite journal | author1 = K G Sumesh | author2 = M R Ramesh Kumar | publisher = Indian Journal of Geo-Marine Sciences | title = Tropical cyclones over NIO during La-Niña Modoki years | url = http://nopr.niscair.res.in/bitstream/123456789/34843/1/IJMS%2044%287%29%20977-983.pdf | format = pdf | date = 2014-03-10 | accessdate = 2017-02-18}}</ref>
The recent discovery of ENSO Modoki has some scientists believing it to be linked to global warming.<ref name="Yeh2009">{{cite journal |last=Yeh |first=Sang-Wook |last2=Kug |first2=Jong-Seong |last3=Dewitte |first3=Boris |last4=Kwon |first4=Min-Ho |last5=Kirtman |first5=Ben P. |last6=Jin |first6=Fei-Fei |date=September 2009 |title=El Niño in a changing climate |journal=Nature |volume=461 |issue=7263 |pages=511–4 |doi=10.1038/nature08316 |bibcode = 2009Natur.461..511Y |pmid=19779449}}</ref> However, comprehensive satellite data go back only to 1979. Generally, there is no scientific consensus on how/if [[climate change]] may affect ENSO.<ref name=Collins10>{{cite journal |last1=Collins |first1=M. |first2=S-I |last2=An |first3=W. |last3=Cai |first4=A. |last4=Ganachaud |first5=E. |last5=Guilyardi |first6=F-F |last6=Jin |first7=M. |last7=Jochum |first8=M. |last8=Lengaigne |first9=S. |last9=Power |first10=A. |last10=Timmermann |first11=G. |last11=Vecchi |first12=A. |last12=Wittenberg |title=The impact of global warming on the tropical Pacific Ocean and El Niño |journal=Nature Geoscience |volume=3 |issue=6 |pages=391–7 |year=2010 |doi=10.1038/ngeo868 |url=|bibcode = 2010NatGe...3..391C }}</ref>
There is also a scientific debate on the very existence of this "new" ENSO. A number of studies dispute the reality of this statistical distinction or its increasing occurrence, or both, either arguing the reliable record is too short to detect such a distinction,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Nicholls |first1=N. |title=Recent trends in the seasonal and temporal behaviour of the El Niño Southern Oscillation |journal=Geophys. Res. Lett. |volume=35 |issue= 19|pages=L19703 |year=2008 |doi= 10.1029/2008GL034499|url= |bibcode=2008GeoRL..3519703N}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=McPhaden |first1=M.J. |first2=T. |last2=Lee |first3=D. |last3=McClurg |title=El Niño and its relationship to changing background conditions in the tropical Pacific Ocean |journal=Geophys. Res. Lett. |volume=38 |issue= 15|pages=L15709 |year=2011 |doi=10.1029/2011GL048275 |url= |bibcode=2011GeoRL..3815709M}}</ref> finding no distinction or trend using other statistical approaches,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Giese |first1=B.S. |first2=S. |last2=Ray |title=El Niño variability in simple ocean data assimilation (SODA), 1871–2008 |journal=J. Geophys. Res. |volume=116 |issue= |pages=C02024 |year=2011 |doi= 10.1029/2010JC006695|url= |bibcode=2011JGRC..116.2024G}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Newman |first1=M. |first2=S.-I. |last2=Shin |first3=M.A. |last3=Alexander |title=Natural variation in ENSO flavors |journal=Geophys. Res. Lett. |volume=38 |issue= 14|pages=L14705 |year=2011 |doi=10.1029/2011GL047658 |url= |bibcode=2011GeoRL..3814705N}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Yeh |first1=S.‐W. |first2=B.P. |last2=Kirtman |first3=J.‐S. |last3=Kug |first4=W. |last4=Park |first5=M. |last5=Latif |title=Natural variability of the central Pacific El Niño event on multi‐centennial timescales |journal=Geophys. Res. Lett. |volume=38 |issue= 2|pages=L02704 |year=2011 |doi=10.1029/2010GL045886 |url= |bibcode=2011GeoRL..38.2704Y}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs13143-011-0011-1 |title=Statistical simulations of the future 50-year statistics of cold-tongue El Niño and warm-pool El Niño |journal=Asia-Pacific J. Atmos. Sci. |volume=47 |issue=3 |pages=223–233 |year=2011 |doi= 10.1007/s13143-011-0011-1 |bibcode= 2011APJAS..47..223N |author1=Hanna Na |author2=Bong-Geun Jang |author3=Won-Moon Choi |author4=Kwang-Yul Kim}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=L'Heureux |first1=M. |last2=Collins |first2=D. |last3=Hu |first3=Z.-Z. |title=Linear trends in sea surface temperature of the tropical Pacific Ocean and implications for the El Niño-Southern Oscillation |journal=Climate Dynamics |volume=40 |issue=5–6 |pages=1–14 |year=2012 |doi=10.1007/s00382-012-1331-2 |url=|bibcode = 2013ClDy...40.1223L }}</ref> or that other types should be distinguished, such as standard and extreme ENSO.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Lengaigne |first1=M. |last2=Vecchi |first2=G. |title=Contrasting the termination of moderate and extreme El Niño events in coupled general circulation models |journal=Climate Dynamics |volume=35 |issue=2–3 |pages=299–313 |year=2010 |doi= 10.1007/s00382-009-0562-3 |url= |bibcode=2010ClDy...35..299L}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Takahashi |first1=K. |first2=A. |last2=Montecinos |first3=K. |last3=Goubanova |first4=B. |last4=Dewitte |title=ENSO regimes: Reinterpreting the canonical and Modoki El Niño |journal=Geophys. Res. Lett. |volume=38 |issue=10 |pages=L10704 |year=2011 |doi=10.1029/2011GL047364 |url= https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-00994266/document|bibcode=2011GeoRL..3810704T}}</ref>
Recent years when La Niña Modoki events occurred include 1973–74, 1975–76, 1983–84, 1988–89, 1998–99, 2000–01, 2008–09, 2010–11 and 2016–17.<ref name="LNM"/><ref name="ENSO SA">{{cite web | author1 = Renata G. Tedeschi | author2 = Iracema F. A. Cavalcanti | publisher = Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais/Centro de Previsão de Tempo e Estudos Climáticos | title = Influência dos ENOS Canônico e Modoki na precipitação da América do Sul | url = http://cbmet2010.web437.uni5.net/anais/artigos/354_23512.pdf | date = 2014-04-23 | language = portuguese | format = PDF | accessdate = 2014-09-27 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141023061148/http://cbmet2010.web437.uni5.net/anais/artigos/354_23512.pdf | archivedate = 23 October 2014 | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="Modoki">{{cite web | author1 = V. Platonov | author2 = E. Semenov | author3 = E. Sokolikhina | publisher = EGU General Assembly/Geophysical Research | title = Extreme La-Nina 2010/11 and the vigorous flood at the north-east of Australia | url = http://meetingorganizer.copernicus.org/EGU2012/EGU2012-313-2.pdf | date = 2014-02-13 | format = PDF | accessdate = 2014-10-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Shinoda |first1=Toshiaki |first2=Harley E. |last2=Hurlburt |first3=E. Joseph |last3=Metzger |title=Anomalous tropical ocean circulation associated with La Niña Modoki |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Oceans |volume=116 |issue=12 |year=2011 |doi=10.1029/2011JC007304 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2011JC007304/abstract |bibcode=2011JGRC..11612001S}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Welsh |first1=Jon |title=Introducing La Nina Modoki: she’s ‘similar but different’… |url=http://www.crdc.com.au/sites/default/files/pdf/SpotSpring16_sc2.pdf|journal=Spotlight Magazine |publisher= Australian Government Cotton Research and Development Corporation |issue=Spring 2016 |year=2011 |pages=34–35 |format=PDF |accessdate=2017-02-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author1=Jon Welsh |publisher=Grain Central | title=Are we heading for a La Niña Modoki? |url=http://www.graincentral.com/weather/are-we-heading-for-a-la-nina-modoki/ |date=2016-10-06 |accessdate=2017-02-18}}</ref>
== See also == * [[2010 Pakistan floods]] (attributed to La Niña) * [[2010–11 Queensland floods]] (attributed to La Niña) * [[2010–12 La Niña event]] * [[2010–13 Southern United States and Mexico drought]] (attributed to La Niña) * [[2011 East Africa drought]] (attributed to La Niña) * [[El Niño–Southern Oscillation]], the atmospheric component of La Niña–El Niño cycle * [[Walker circulation]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://www.pmel.noaa.gov/elnino/what-is-la-nina What is La Niña?] at [http://www.pmel.noaa.gov/elnino NOAA Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory] * [http://www.pmel.noaa.gov/elnino/lanina-faq La Niña FAQs] at [http://www.pmel.noaa.gov/elnino NOAA Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory] * [http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/analysis_monitoring/lanina/cold_impacts.shtml La Niña episodes in the Tropical Pacific] at [[Climate Prediction Center|CPC]] * [http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/precip/CWlink/MJO/enso.shtml El Niño–Southern Oscillation (ENSO)] at CPC * [http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/analysis_monitoring/ensostuff/ensoyears.shtml List of El Niño and La Niña events since 1950] at CPC

revision.text:
'''List of Salticidae species D–F''' includes all described species with a scientific name starting from D to F of the spider family [[Salticidae]] as of December 16, 2016.<ref>{{cite web |date=2016 |url=http://www.wsc.nmbe.ch/family/83/Salticidae |title=Family: Salticidae |work=World Spider Catalog | version=17.5 |publisher=Natural History Museum Bern |accessdate=2016-12-18 }}</ref>
{{main|List of Salticidae species}}
==''Damoetas''== ''[[Damoetas]]'' <small>Peckham & Peckham, 1886</small> * ''[[Damoetas nitidus]]'' <small>(L. Koch, 1880)</small> – Queensland, New South Wales
==''Darwinneon''== ''[[Darwinneon]]'' <small>Cutler, 1971</small> * ''[[Darwinneon crypticus]]'' <small>Cutler, 1971</small> – Galapagos Islands
==''Dasycyptus''== ''[[Dasycyptus]]'' <small>Simon, 1902</small> * ''[[Dasycyptus dimus]]'' <small>Simon, 1902</small> [[type species]] – Gabon, Congo * ''[[Dasycyptus dubius]]'' <small>Berland & Millot, 1941</small> – Ivory Coast
==''Dendryphantes''== ''[[Dendryphantes]]'' <small>C. L. Koch, 1837</small> * ''[[Dendryphantes acutus]]'' <small>Wesołowska & Haddad, 2014</small> – Lesotho * ''[[Dendryphantes aethiopicus]]'' <small>Wesołowska & Tomasiewicz, 2008</small> – Ethiopia * ''[[Dendryphantes amphibolus]]'' <small>Chamberlin, 1916</small> – Peru * ''[[Dendryphantes andinus]]'' <small>Chamberlin, 1916</small> – Peru * ''[[Dendryphantes arboretus]]'' <small>Wesołowska & Cumming, 2008</small> – Zimbabwe * ''[[Dendryphantes barguzinensis]]'' <small>Danilov, 1997</small> – Russia * ''[[Dendryphantes barrosmachadoi]]'' <small>Caporiacco, 1955</small> – Venezuela * ''[[Dendryphantes biankii]]'' <small>Prószyński, 1979</small> – Russia, Mongolia, China * ''[[Dendryphantes bisquinquepunctatus]]'' <small>Taczanowski, 1878</small> – Peru * ''[[Dendryphantes calus]]'' <small>Chamberlin, 1916</small> – Peru * ''[[Dendryphantes caporiaccoi]]'' <small>Roewer, 1951</small> – Karakorum * ''[[Dendryphantes centromaculatus]]'' <small>Taczanowski, 1878</small> – Peru * ''[[Dendryphantes chuldensis]]'' <small>Prószyński, 1982</small> – Mongolia * ''[[Dendryphantes comatus]]'' <small>Karsch, 1880</small> – Syria * ''[[Dendryphantes czekanowskii]]'' <small>Prószyński, 1979</small> – Russia * ''[[Dendryphantes darchan]]'' <small>Logunov, 1993</small> – Mongolia * ''[[Dendryphantes duodecempunctatus]]'' <small>Mello-Leitão, 1943</small> – Argentina * ''[[Dendryphantes elgonensis]]'' <small>Wesołowska & Dawidowicz, 2014</small> – Kenya * ''[[Dendryphantes fulvipes]]'' <small>(Mello-Leitão, 1943)</small> – Chile * ''[[Dendryphantes fulviventris]]'' <small>(Lucas, 1846)</small> – Algeria * ''[[Dendryphantes fusconotatus]]'' <small>(Grube, 1861)</small> – Russia, Mongolia, China * ''[[Dendryphantes hararensis]]'' <small>Wesołowska & Cumming, 2008</small> – Zimbabwe, South Africa * ''[[Dendryphantes hastatus]]'' <small>(Clerck, 1757)</small> [[type species]] – Palearctic * ''[[Dendryphantes hewitti]]'' <small>Lessert, 1925</small> – Kenya, Tanzania * ''[[Dendryphantes holmi]]'' <small>Wesołowska & Dawidowicz, 2014</small> – Kenya * ''[[Dendryphantes honestus]]'' <small>(C. L. Koch, 1846)</small> – Brazil * ''[[Dendryphantes legibilis]]'' <small>(Nicolet, 1849)</small> – Chile * ''[[Dendryphantes lepidus]]'' <small>(Peckham & Peckham, 1901)</small> – Brazil * ''[[Dendryphantes limpopo]]'' <small>Wesołowska & Haddad, 2013</small> – South Africa * ''[[Dendryphantes linzhiensis]]'' <small>Hu, 2001</small> – China * ''[[Dendryphantes luridus]]'' <small>Wesołowska & Dawidowicz, 2014</small> – Kenya * ''[[Dendryphantes madrynensis]]'' <small>Mello-Leitão, 1940</small> – Argentina * ''[[Dendryphantes matumi]]'' <small>Haddad & Wesołowska, 2013</small> – South Africa * ''[[Dendryphantes mendicus]]'' <small>(C. L. Koch, 1846)</small> – West Indies * ''[[Dendryphantes minutus]]'' <small>Wesołowska & Dawidowicz, 2014</small> – Kenya * ''[[Dendryphantes modestus]]'' <small>(Mello-Leitão, 1941)</small> – Argentina * ''[[Dendryphantes mordax]]'' <small>(C. L. |- |Citrus mosaic ||[[Satsuma dwarf-related virus]] |- |Bud union crease ||Virus for some combinations, otherwise genetic or unknown |- |Citrus leaf rugose ||genus [[Ilarvirus]], [[Citrus leaf rugose virus]] (CLRV) |- |Citrus yellow mosaic ||genus [[Badnavirus]] |- |Crinkly leaf ||[[Crinkly leaf virus]] (strain of [[Citrus variegation virus]]) |- |Infectious variegation ||genus [[Ilarvirus]], [[Citrus variegation virus]] (CVV) |- |Navel infectious mottling ||[[Satsuma dwarf-related virus]] |- |Psorosis ||[[Citrus psorosis virus]] (CPsV) |- |Satsuma dwarf ||[[Satsuma dwarf virus]] (SDV) |- |Tatter leaf = citrange stunt ||genus [[Capillovirus]], [[Citrus tatter leaf virus]] (probably a closely related strain of [[Apple stem grooving virus]] rather than a distinct virus |- |Tristeza = decline and stem pitting, seedling yellows ||genus [[Closterovirus]], [[Citrus tristeza virus]] (CTV) |- |Citrus Leprosis Virus type I & II |} ==Viroids and graft-transmissible pathogens [GTP]== {| class="wikitable" style="clear" ! colspan=2| '''Viroids and graft-transmissible pathogens [GTP]'''
|- |Algerian navel orange virus ||GTP |- |Blight = young tree decline, rough lemon decline ||GTP |- |Blind pocket ||GTP |- |Cachexia ||Citrus cachexia viroid (Hostuviroid) |- |Chlorotic dwarf ||White-fly transmitted GTP |- |Citrus dwarfing ||Various viroids |- |Citrus yellow mottle ||GTP |- |Citrus yellow ringspot ||GTP |- |Concave gum ||GTP |- |Cristacortis ||GTP |- |Exocortis ||[[Citrus exocortis viroid]] (CEVd) [[Pospiviroidae]] |- |Fatal yellows ||GTP |- |Gummy bark ||GTP, possible viroid |- |Gum pocket and gummy pittings ||GTP, possible viroid |- |Impietratura ||GTP |- |Indian citrus ringspot ||GTP |- |Leaf curl ||GTP |- |Leathery leaf ||GTP |- |Leprosis ||GTP associated with Brevipalpus spp. mites |- |Measles ||GTP |- |Milam stem-pitting ||GTP |- |Multiple sprouting disease ||GTP |- |Nagami kumquat disease ||GTP |- |Ringspot diseases ||Various GTPs |- |Vein enation = woody gall ||GTP (possible luteovirus) |- |Xyloporosis = cachexia ||Citrus cachexia viroid (Hostuviroid) |- |Yellow vein ||GTP |- |Yellow vein clearing of lemon ||GTP |- |} == Phytoplasmal and spiroplasmal diseases == {| class="wikitable" style="clear" ! colspan=2| '''Phytoplasmal and spiroplasmal diseases'''
|- |Australian citrus dieback ||''Unknown procaryote? |- |[[Citrus stubborn disease|Stubborn]] ||''[[Spiroplasma citri]]'' (spread by leafhoppers) |- |Witches’ broom of lime ||[[Phytoplasma]] |- |} ==Miscellaneous diseases and disorders== {| class="wikitable" style="clear" ! colspan=2| '''Miscellaneous diseases and disorders'''
|- |Algal disease (algal spot) ||''Cephaleuros virescens'' |- |Amachamiento ||Unknown |- |Blossom-end clearing ||Physiological |- |Chilling injury ||Cold temperatures |- |Citrus blight ||Unknown - pathogen suspected |- |Creasing ||Nutritional (?) |- |Crinkle scurf ||Genetic |- |Granulation ||Physiological |- |Lemon sieve-tube necrosis ||Unknown, but hereditary |- |Lime blotch = wood pocket ||Inherited chimeral agent |- |Membranous stain ||Cold temperatures |- |Mesophyll collapse ||Unknown |- |Oleocellosis ||Physiological |- |Postharvest pitting ||Physiological |- |Puffing ||Physiological |- |Rind breakdown ||Physiological |- |Rind staining ||Physiological |- |Rind stipple of grapefruit ||Environmental |- |Rumple of lemon fruit ||Unknown |- |Shell bark complex ||Unknown - (viroid?) |- |Sooty mold (superficial, not pathogenic) ||''Capnodium''
''C. citricola''
''Capnodium'' sp. |- |Stem-end rind breakdown ||Physiological |- |Stylar-end breakdown of Tahiti lime ||Physiological |- |Stylar-end rind breakdown ||Physiological |- |Stylar-end rot ||Physiological |- |Sunburn ||Excessive heat and light |- |Tangerine dieback ||Unknown |- |Water spot ||Physiological |- |Woody galls on stems ||Bruchophagus fellis (Citrus Gall Wasp) |- |Zebra skin ||Physiological |- |} ==References== *[http://www.apsnet.org/publications/commonnames/Pages/Citrus.aspx Common Names of Diseases, The American Phytopathological Society] {{Citrus}} [[Category:Citrus diseases|*]] [[Category:Lists of plant diseases|Citrus]]

page.title: List of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2018

revision.comment: Expanded Mass gas explosions with reference to NTSB report
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}}
{{Use American English|date=May 2016}} The following is a '''list of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2018'''. It is one of several [[list of pipeline accidents in the United States|lists of U.S. pipeline accidents]]. See also [[list of natural gas and oil production accidents in the United States]]. {{expand list|date=April 2013}} __NOTOC__ <!--begin temporary compact toc--> <!-- something nicer-looking and more navigable should be done here; this is a temporary TOC to ease navigation --> <!-- | bgcolor=#dddddd align=center colspan=11 | See also – [[#References|References]] --> <!--end compact toc-->
== Incidents ==
This is not a complete list of all pipeline accidents. '''For natural gas alone''', the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA), a United States Department of Transportation agency, has collected data on more than 3,200 accidents deemed serious or significant since 1987.
A "significant incident" results in any of the following consequences: * fatality or injury requiring in-patient hospitalization * $50,000 or more in total costs, measured in 1984 dollars * liquid releases of five or more barrels (42 US gal/barrel) * releases resulting in an unintentional fire or explosion
PHMSA and the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) post incident data and results of investigations into accidents involving pipelines that carry a variety of products, including natural gas, oil, diesel fuel, gasoline, kerosene, jet fuel, carbon dioxide, and other substances. Occasionally pipelines are repurposed to carry different products.<ref>Data sets of PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents for 1986-2001, 2002-2009, and 2010-2017 can be downloaded from the tab by that name on the PHMSA's Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/data-and-statistics/pipeline/pipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2018.01.10. PHMSA Corrective Action Orders are at https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/CAO_opid_0.html. PHMSA Pipeline Failure Investigation Reports are at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/safety-reports/pipeline-failure-investigation-reports. NTSB Pipeline Accident Reports are at https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/pipeline.aspx.</ref>
* On January 8, a 12-inch pipeline was damaged and leaked 500 barrels (27,500 gallons) of gasoline in [[Eagan, MN]]. No injuries were reported however gasoline flowed into the stormwater system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kstp.com/news/gas-leak-evacuation-lifetime-fitness-eagan/4735564/|title=500 Barrels of Gasoline Leak After Pipeline Ruptures in Eagan, Company Says|publisher=}}</ref> According to Magellan Midstream Partners, the owner of the pipeline, a contractor the company hired accidentally struck and broke open the pipeline that runs from Rosemount to Minneapolis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kstp.com/news/eagan-gas-spill-cold-weather-minimize-environmental-damage/4739056/|title=Cold Weather Helped Minimize Environmental Damage From Eagan Gas Spill|publisher=}}</ref> * On January 10, a pipeline in [[Pearl City, Hawaii]] ruptured and leaked an estimated 500 gallons of fuel oil into two residents' yards.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/news/2018/01/10/hawaiian-electric-pipeline-leaks-500-gallons-of.html |title=Hawaiian Electric pipeline leaks 500 gallons of fuel oil into two Pearl City yards |last=Mai |first=HJ |date= January 10, 2018|website=bizjournals.com |publisher=Pacific Business News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/37231915/heco-underground-pipeline-bursts-spilling-500-gallons-of-fuel|title=Oil pipeline leak makes a big mess in Pearl City|first=HNN Staff, Ashley|last=Nagaoka|publisher=}}</ref> The state Department of Health says a small amount of oil entered the stream.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://khon2.com/2018/01/10/cleanup-underway-after-oil-leaks-from-underground-pipeline-in-pearl-city/|title=Cleanup underway after oil leaks from underground pipeline in Pearl City|date=January 11, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> * On January 14, a natural gas pipeline ruptured, leading to a fire in [[Geismar, Louisiana]]. No injuries or fatalities were reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theadvocate.com/baton_rouge/news/crime_police/article_6c30730e-f963-11e7-8fd8-7bef81f19e34.html|title=Cause still unknown of natural gas leak, fire in Geismar; gas line rupture in East Iberville repaired|first=Advocate staff|last=report|publisher=}}</ref> * On January 30, a crew using a boring drill hit a natural gas pipe, in [[Arlington, Texas]]. Escaping gas ignited, and burned for over 3 hours. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://arlingtonvoice.com/arlington/crime-emergency/2018/01/30/natural-gas-pipeline-fire-causes-collins-closure|title=Natural gas pipeline fire causes Collins closure|date=January 30, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> * On January 31, a gas pipeline exploded and burned in [[Noble County, Ohio]]. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mariettatimes.com/news/2018/02/pipeline-explosion-in-noble-county/|title=Pipeline explosion in Noble County - News, Sports, Jobs - Marietta Times|website=www.mariettatimes.com}}</ref> * On February 18, a 16-inch crude oil pipeline ruptured in [[Yukon, Oklahoma]]. Oil accumulated in a 7-acre private pond. About 84,000 gallons of crude were spilled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koco.com/article/crews-cleaning-oil-spill-at-yukon-pond/18222699|title=Oil spill cleanup underway at pond near Yukon neighborhood|date=February 20, 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chem.info/news/2018/02/oil-spill-cleanup-underway-suburban-oklahoma-city|title=Oil Spill Cleanup Underway In Suburban Oklahoma City|date=February 21, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> * On February 23, a house in a suburb of [[Dallas, Texas]] exploded, killing a girl, and injuring 4 others in her family. This followed a number of gas distribution line leaks in that area over the previous months. Atmos crew then started large scale replacement of gas lines in that area, resulting in at least 2,800 homes being without gas service for days to weeks. NTSB Investigators were sent to the area.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/gas-service-stops-for-thousands-of-dallas-homes-due-to-leaks/|title=Gas service stops for thousands of Dallas homes due to leaks|date=March 1, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> * On March 3, a fallen electric wire from a utility pole caused a gas line to rupture and burn, in [[Wenham, Massachusetts]]. There were no injuries reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wenham.wickedlocal.com/news/20180302/wenham-police-and-fire-respond-after-downed-utility-pole-ignites-underground-gas-line|title=Wenham Police and Fire respond after downed utility pole ignites underground gas line|publisher=}}</ref> * On March 21, a [Marathon] pipeline spilled about 42,000 gallons of diesel fuel, near [[Solitude, Indiana]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tristatehomepage.com/news/local-news/location-of-pipeline-leak-found-1098-barrels-recovered-in-posey-county/1074347641|title=Location of pipeline leak found, 1,098 barrels recovered in Posey County|first=Amanda|last=Mueller|date=March 24, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> * On May 10, a crude oil pipeline ruptured in [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]], leaving a film of crude on a school playground, homes and automobiles. At least 630 gallons of crude were released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news9.com/story/38172455/cleanup-continues-after-crude-oil-leak-in-nw-okc|title=Cleanup Continues After Crude Oil Leak In NW OKC|first=Caleigh|last=Bourgeois|publisher=}}</ref> * On May 14, a tractor crashed into a valve on an NGL pipeline in [[St. Mary Parish, Louisiana]], releasing a cloud of a blend of propane, butane, ethane and natural gasoline. Residents and two schools were evacuated for several hours. There was no fire or explosion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.katc.com/story/38187840/residents-explain-pipeline-leak-scare-before-the-smoke-all-cleared|title=Residents explain pipeline leak scare, before the smoke all cleared|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.katc.com/story/38182211/chemical-in-leak-identified-shelters-and-school-closures-established|title=All evacuations, road closures lifted in St. Mary Parish; the leak has been stopped|publisher=}}</ref> * On May 23, a pipeline rupture and fire in [[Bienville Parish, Louisiana]] forced at least 30 nearby residents to evacuate. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ksla.com/story/38266273/all-clear-issued-after-bienville-parish-gas-well-fire-residents-allowed-home|title=All clear issued after Bienville Parish gas well fire, residents allowed home|first=KSLA|last=Staff|publisher=}}</ref> * On June 7, a 36-inch natural gas transmission pipeline exploded and burned, near [[Wheeling, West Virginia]]. There were no injuries. The pipeline went into service in January 2018. Shifting land was identified as the cause.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://seekingalpha.com/news/3362447-transcanada-declares-force-majeure-west-virginia-gas-explosion|title=TransCanada declares force majeure on West Virginia gas after explosion|first=SA Editor Carl|last=Surran|date=June 7, 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/local/region/2018/06/07/Pipeline-explosion-moundsville-west-virginia/stories/201806070129|title=Officials: W.Va. explosion was along newly installed natural gas line|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wvpublic.org/post/feds-say-land-shift-likely-caused-explosion-pipeline-still-risk#stream/0|title=Feds Say Land Shift Likely Caused Explosion, Pipeline Still at Risk|first=Brittany|last=Patterson|publisher=}}</ref> * On June 14, a gas pipeline in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]] was ruptured by a tractor. A Firefighter and four Oklahoma Natural Gas workers were injured in the explosion and fire that followed the rupture. An initial report said one of the injured was a bystander.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.10tv.com/article/firefighter-5-others-injured-tulsa-gas-explosion|title=Firefighter, 5 others injured in Tulsa gas explosion|date=June 15, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> * On June 15, A Southern Star Central Natural Gas pipeline exploded outside [[Hesston, Kansas]], sending flames shooting 75 to 100 feet into the sky<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/southern-star-natural-gas-pipeline-explosion-hesston-kansas/|title=Natural gas pipeline explosion rocks rural Kansas|publisher=}}</ref> * On June 19, a [[Sunoco]] pipeline leaked more than 33,000 gallons of gasoline into a creek, near [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]. PHMSA said it first learned of the spill on the evening of June 19 from a “private citizen” who reported a petroleum odor at Darby Creek. About two-thirds of the spill was recovered.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2018/09/04/sunocos-12-inch-pipeline-leaked-33000-gallons-of-gasoline-into-creek-phmsa-says/|title=Sunoco’s 12-inch pipeline leaked 33,000 gallons of gasoline into creek, PHMSA says - StateImpact Pennsylvania|publisher=}}</ref> * On August 1, a series of gas pipeline explosions injured seven pipeline workers and firefighters in [[Midland County, Texas]]. One injured worker later died. They were responding to a leak report.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gosanangelo.com/story/news/local/texas/2018/08/05/official-one-dead-after-pipeline-explosion-near-midland/911494002/|title=Official: One dead after pipeline explosion near Midland|publisher=}}</ref> * On September 6, a 6 inch [[Dominion Energy]] gas gathering pipeline burned, near [[Clarksburg, West Virginia]]. Lightning was suspected of hitting the pipeline.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wboy.com/news/emergencies/crews-responded-to-gas-well-fire-in-harrison-county/1424220515|title=Crews responded to gas well fire in Harrison County|first=Jonah|last=Marcum|date=September 7, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> * On September 7, a [[Buckeye Partners]] pipeline ruptured in [[Decatur, Indiana]], spilling about 8,000 gallons of jet fuel into the [[St. Marys River (Indiana and Ohio)]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wane.com/news/local-news/safety-warning-decatur-fuel-leak-in-saint-mary-s-river/1426405418|title=Safety warning: Decatur fuel leak|first=Terra|last=Brantley|date=September 8, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> * On September 10, a 24 inch [[Energy Transfer Partners]] gas transmission pipeline exploded and burned, in [[Center Township, Beaver County, Pennsylvania]]. One home, 2 garages, and 6 steel high tension power line towers were destroyed, but no injuries were reported. The pipeline had been operating for 1 week before the failure. Earth movement was suspected as the cause.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://triblive.com/local/regional/14064921-74/early-morning-pipeline-blast-forces-evacuations-in-beaver-county|title=Heavy rain contributed to Beaver County pipeline blast|first=Tom Davidson and Tony|last=LaRussa|website=TribLIVE.com}}</ref> * On September 13, the [[Massachusetts gas explosions]] destroyed 40 homes, killed one person and 21 were sent to the hospital. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newshub.co.nz/home/world/2018/09/huge-gas-explosion-in-boston-us-engulfs-multiple-buildings.html|title=Boston gas explosions injure three|date=September 14, 2018|publisher=}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |title=NTSB/PSR-18/02 |url=https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/PSR1802.pdf |publisher=National Transportation Safety Board |accessdate=16 November 2018}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}} {{List of pipeline accidents in the United States|state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Lists of pipeline accidents in the United States]] [[Category:2018 disasters in the United States]]

[[cetacean stranding|Strandings]] of [[sperm whale]]s have occurred across much of their global range. About 60 per cent of the world's recorded sperm whale strandings occur in three regions - [[Tasmania]], [[New Zealand]] and the [[North Sea]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = http://www.wildlifeextra.com/go/news/tasmania-stranding.html|title = 50 sperm whales die after stranding in Tasmania|date = |accessdate = 2014-12-12|website = WildlifeExtra.com|publisher = }}</ref> 132 strandings of sperm whales were recorded around the coast of the United Kingdom (mostly in Scotland) between 1990 and 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.wildlifeextra.com/go/news/redcar-whale.html|title = Sperm whale dies on Redcar beach|date = 2011|accessdate = 2014-12-12|website = WildlifeExtra.com|publisher = }}</ref> The list below is in reverse chronological order and is not exhaustive.

Progress report on cetacean research, January 2007 to December 2007, with statistical data for the calendar year 2007|last = Gedamke|first = Jason|publisher = Australian Antarctic Division Department of Environment, Water, Heritage and the Arts|year = 2008|isbn = |location = Tasmania, Australia|pages = 14|url = http://www.marinemammals.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0014/518/Australia-IWC60-Progress-Report.pdf}}</ref> |- |2006 |October 25 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |One Mile Beach, east of [[Hopetoun, Western Australia|Hopetoun]], Western Australia |1 |1 |0 |Washed ashore, already dead.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2006-10-25/dead-sperm-whale-washes-ashore/1294322|title = Dead sperm whale washes ashore|date = 2006-10-25|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-14|publisher = ABC}}</ref> |- |2006 |October 24 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |[[Bremer Bay]], Western Australia |5 |5 |0 |Died after beaching themselves. One whale was 20 m away from the others. Sizes ranged from 9.7 m to 12.5 m.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.perthnow.com.au/five-whales-stranded-on-beach/story-e6frg4iu-1111112413954?nk=cda22362a15a4871829a3d1e9a82f811|title = Five whales stranded on beach|date = 2006-10-24|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-14|publisher = PerthNow}}</ref> |- |2006 |August |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |[[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]], New South Wales |1 |1 |0 |Washed ashore dead bearing deep cuts believed caused by propeller strike from a large commercial vessel.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Nomination for listing a key threatening process under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act) - Death or injury to marine species as a direct result of boat strike on the east coast of Australia.|publisher = Australian Government - Department of the Environment|year = 2007|isbn = |location = Australia|pages = 2, 20|url = http://www.environment.gov.au/system/files/pages/87ef6ac7-da62-4a45-90ec-0d473863f3e6/files/nomination-boat-strike-2007.pdf}}</ref> |- |2006 |August |{{Flagicon|New Zealand}} New Zealand |[[Port Waikato]] |1 |1 |0 |Juvenile female sperm whale (7.2m) with visible injuries inflicted from by fishing line entanglement. Washed up dead.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.wildlifeextra.com/go/news/news-nzspermwhale.html|title = Sperm whale probably killed by fishing line|date = 2006|accessdate = 2014-12-12|website = WildlifeExtra.com|publisher = }}</ref> |- |2006 |June 1 |{{Flagicon|Tunisia}} Tunisian Republic |[[Bizerte]], Cap Zbib |1 |1 |0 |16 m male.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|jstor = 10.2307/40863900|title = A Survey of Cetaceans Stranded along the Northern Coast of Tunisia: Recent Findings (2005-2008) and a Short Review of the Literature|last = Attia El Hili|first = Hedia|date=September 2010|journal = Journal of Coastal Research|doi = |pmid = |volume = 26|edition = 5|display-authors=etal}}</ref> |- |2005 |December 13 |{{Flagicon|Tunisia}} Tunisian Republic |[[Tabarka]] |1 |1 |0 |7.6 m partial body found. Female.<ref name=":5" /> |- |2005 |March 7 |{{Flagicon|Republic of Ireland}} Ireland |Belgooly Creek, [[Kinsale]], Cork |1 |1 |0 |14 m male found decomposed.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|jstor = 10.2307/25536827|title = Records from the Irish Whale and Dolphin Group for 2005|last = Philpott|first = E.|date = 2007|journal = The Irish Naturalists' Journal|doi = |pmid = |last2 = Rogan|first2 = E.|edition = 10|volume = 28}}</ref> |- |2005 |February 22 |{{Flagicon|UK}} UK |[[Fair Head]], [[Antrim, Ireland|Antrim, Northern Ireland]] |1 |1 |0 |15 m male found decomposed.<ref name=":4" /> |- |2005 |February 7 |{{Flagicon|UK}} UK |Garron Point, [[Antrim, Ireland|Antrim, Northern Ireland]] |1 |1 |0 |11 m male found decomposed.<ref name=":4" /> |- |2005 |January 17 |{{Flagicon|Republic of Ireland}} Ireland |Long Strand, Castlefreke, Cork |1 |1 |0 |10 m male found decomposed.<ref name=":4" /> |- |2004 |June 16 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Ocean Beach and Macquarie Harbour, Strahan, Tasmania |5 |4 |1 |Four sperm whales found dead on Ocean Beach. Another, thought to be from same pod was rescued after becoming stranded in Macquarie Harbour at Strahan.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url = http://www.theage.com.au/news/National/Whales-in-mass-stranding/2004/11/29/1101577379274.html?from=moreStories|title = More whales die in island beaching|date = 2004-11-29|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-14|newspaper = The Age}}</ref> |- |2003 |November 30 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Arthurs Bay, Flinders Island, Tasmania |10 |9 |1 |<ref name=":6" /> |- |2003 |September 25 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Doubtful Island Bay, near [[Bremer Bay, Western Australia|Bremer Bay]], Western Australia |9 |9 |0 |All badly gashed, at least 6 were dead at time of first inspection. Were neither rescued nor euthanased.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/09/25/1064083134594.html?from=storyrhs|title = Gashed whales washed ashore in Western Australia|date = 2003-09-26|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-14|newspaper = The Age}}</ref> |- |2003 | |{{Flagicon|New Zealand}} New Zealand |Karekare beach, West Auckland |12 | | |<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://collections.tepapa.govt.nz/exhibitions/whales/segment.aspx?irn=213|title = Whales - Tohora|date = |accessdate = 2014-12-27|website = Museum of New Zealand|publisher = }}</ref> |- |1997 |March |{{Flagicon|UK}} UK |[[Firth of Forth]], Scotland |1 |1 |0 |40 ft long male, nicknamed 'Moby' <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/rescuers-grieve-as-moby-dies-on-sands-at-airth-1264552.html|title=Rescuers grieve as Moby dies on sands at Airth|date=1997-03-31|access-date=2016-08-18}}</ref> |- |1995 |January |{{Flagicon|Netherlands}}Netherlands |[[Scheveningen]] |3 |3 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1994 |November |{{Flagicon|Belgium}} Belgium |Koksijde/Nieuwpoort |4 |4 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1994 |October 29 |{{Flagicon|New Zealand}} New Zealand |[[Muriwai Beach]], [[Auckland, New Zealand|Auckland]] |72 | | |<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url = http://www.wainuibeach.co.nz/WAINUI%20INFO/whales.html|title = OUR HISTORY: The Day The Whales Died|date = |accessdate = 2014-12-26|website = Wainui Beach|publisher = |last = Clapham|first = Gray}}</ref> |- |1991 |December |{{Flagicon|Denmark}} Denmark |[[Fanø]] |3 |3 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1989 |September 2 |{{Flagicon|USA}}USA |West of Sabine Pass, [[Galveston, Texas]] |1 |1 |0 |3 week old calf, found stranded in surf and taken into care at Sea-Arama aquarium. Suffered a "pneumonia-like" lung infection and died a week after being discovered.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Whale dies after washing ashore - Galveston, Texas (1989) - on Newspapers.com|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4293675/whale_dies_after_washing_ashore/|website = Newspapers.com|access-date = 2016-02-12}}</ref> |- |1984 |February 9 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |[[Perkins Bay]], Stanley, Tasmania |8 |8 |0 |<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article126877925|title = Sperm whales die on beach in Tasmania|date = 1982-02-11|work = |accessdate = |newspaper = The Canberra Times}}</ref> |- |1984 |January |{{Flagicon|Netherlands}}Netherlands |Henne, Strand |2 |2 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1983 |April 19 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Prion Beach, south coast, Tasmania |1 |1 |0 |Single dead animal approx 25 ft long, rolling in surf. Said to be 'nearly white' in colour.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = http://eprints.utas.edu.au/14028/1/1984__McManus_cetacean.pdf|title = Cetacean strandings in Tasmania from February 1978 to May 1983|last = McManus|first = T.J.|date = 1984|journal = Papers and proceedings of the Royal Society of Tasmania, Vol. 118|accessdate = 2014-12-11|doi = |pmid = |display-authors=etal}}</ref> |- |1983 |January 14 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Temma, west coast, Tasmania |1 |1 |0 |Single adult female washed up dead. Adult female 11.1 m long.<ref name=":0" /> |- |1982 |October |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Ringarooma Bay, Tasmania |1 |1 |0 |Putrid carcass found weeks after stranding.<ref name=":0" /> |- |1982 |February 9 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Perkins Bay, Stanley, Tasmania |9 |5 |4 |Nine animals observed swimming offshore, 1 hour before the second lowest spring ebb tide for February. Stranded later, four refloated after midnight. Five females remained, all were dead the next evening. Lengths ranged from 10.4 to 11.25 m.<ref name=":0" /> |- |1982 |January 26 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Ocean Beach, Strahan, Tasmania |14 |14 |0 |Carcasses were found already decomposing. one female had aborted or evulsed a 3.96 m male foetus. 3 males, 11 females. Largest male was 14.3 m, largest female was 11.65 m long.<ref name=":0" /> |- |1982 |January 23 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Perkins Bay, Stanley, Tasmania |1 |1 |0 |Adult female 10.6m long. Next day it evulsed a 4.1 m male calf.<ref name=":0" /> |- |1981 |September 25 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Fotheringate Bay, Flinders Island, Tasmania |2 |2 |0 |Two mature males, 16m and 16.2m. Had been dead for about 2 weeks. In advanced stage of decomposition.<ref name=":0" /> |- |1981 |January 15 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Macquarie Harbour, Strahan, Tasmania |26 |17 |8 |Nine animals returned to deep water, five voluntarily and four with assistance. One later restranded and died.<ref name=":0" /> |- |1980 |March |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |South of Trial Harbour, Tasmania |3 |3 |0 |Decomposing corpses of three animals.<ref name=":0" /> |- |1979 |June 16 |{{Flagicon|USA}}USA |[[Siuslaw River]], Oregon |41 | | |Event detailed in scientific paper.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.academia.edu/3182128/A_MASS_STRANDING_OF_SPERM_WHALES_IN_OREGON_SEX_AND_AGE_COMPOSITION_OF_THE_SCHOOL|title = A MASS STRANDING OF SPERM WHALES IN OREGON: SEX AND AGE COMPOSITION OF THE SCHOOL|date = 1986|accessdate = 2014-12-27|website = Academia.edu|publisher = |last = Harvey|first = James}}</ref> |- |1979 |February 1 |{{Flagicon|Mexico}} Mexico |Isla del Espiritu Santo |1 | | |14.39 m male.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|title = Recent Stranding of Sperm Whales in the Gulf of California, Mexico|last = Vidal|first = Omar|date=November 1986|journal = Journal of Mammalogy|doi = 10.2307/1381147|pmid = |last2 = Findley|first2 = Lloyd T.|volume = 67|edition = 4|pages = 770–771|jstor=1381147}}</ref> |- |1979 |January 1 |{{Flagicon|Mexico}} Mexico |San Bruno, 15 km north of Mulege, Baja California Sur |56 | | |38 males, 9 females, 3 aborted fetuses (none of which appeared to be full term), 9 of undetermined sex.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = Beached whales puzzling - Mulege, Mexico (1979) - on Newspapers.com|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4293390/beached_whales_puzzling_mulege/|website = Newspapers.com|access-date = 2016-02-12}}</ref> |- |1978 |August 29 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Settlement Beach, [[Flinders Island, Tasmania|Flinders Island]], Tasmania |1 | | |Single large animal.<ref name=":0" /> |- |1978 |July |{{Flagicon|Mexico}} Mexico |[[Isla San José (Baja California Sur)|Isla San José]], Baja California Sur |1 | | |11 m long. Sex undetermined.<ref name=":3" /> |- |1976 |September 30 |{{Flagicon|USA}}USA |[[Samoa Peninsula]] 1.6 km north of the entrance to [[Humboldt Bay, California|Humboldt Bay]], California |1 |1 |0 |Decomposition prevented sex determination. A prominent dorsal hump and seven distinct knuckles or crenulations extended posteriorly down the back. Numerous crescent-shaped shark wounds were evident along the venter, back, and tailstock. |- |1975 |July |{{Flagicon|USA}}USA |[[Humboldt Bay, California|Humboldt Bay]], California |1 |1 |0 |Adult female, found floating in bay. Towed to sea for disposal. Washed ashore 4.8 km south of Humboldt Bay. |- |1975 | |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Patriarchs Inlet, [[Flinders Island, Tasmania|Flinders Island]], Tasmania |3 |3 |0 |Remains of three animals.<ref name=":0" /> |- |1973 |September 1 |{{Flagicon|Mexico}} Mexico |Huatabampito, [[Sonora, Mexico|Sonora]] |17 | | |Sex not determined.<ref name=":3" /> |- |1973 |July 30 |{{Flagicon|USA}}USA |Shelter Cove, Humboldt, California |1 |1 |0 |10.2 n long. Badly decomposed, sex undetermined. |- |1972 | |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |[[Strahan, Tasmania|Strahan]], Tasmania |27 | | |Rescue attempts were made<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article127215445|title = Government plans whale rescue plan|date = 1984-07-22|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-10|newspaper = The Canberra Times}}</ref> |- |1970 |June 26 |{{Flagicon|USA}}USA |Agate Beach, 1.0 km north of Patricks Point State Park, California |1 |1 |0 |Adult male. |- |1970 |March 17 |{{Flagicon|New Zealand}} New Zealand |Wainui Beach, Gisborne |59 | | |Combination of males, females and their young. Detailed account online.<ref name=":7" /> |- |1954 |December 28 |{{Flagicon|Mexico}} Mexico |[[San Felipe, Baja California|San Felipe]], Baja California Norte |1 | | |13 m male.<ref name=":3" /> |- |1954 |July 14 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |[[Middleton Beach, Western Australia|Middleton Beach]], Albany, Western Australia |1 | | |13 ft long, calf.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28662967|title = Whale calf on beach in W.A.|date = 1954-07-18|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-10|newspaper = The Sun-Herald}}</ref> Alive when first sighted.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article52955095|title = Albany has a whale of a problem|date = 1954-07-15|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-10|newspaper = The West Australian}}</ref> |- |1954 |January 16 |{{Flagicon|Mexico}} Mexico |[[La Paz, Baja California Sur|La Paz]], Baja California Sur |22 | | |All bulls.<ref name=":3" /> |- |1953 |December 12 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |mouth of [[Pioneer River, Queensland|Pioneer River]], Brisbane, Queensland |1 |1 |0 |50 ft long.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article131240141|title = Frantic bid to dislodge dead whale|date = 1953-12-12|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-10|newspaper = News}}</ref> |- |1953 |July 15 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Tallow Beach, [[Byron Bay]], New South Wales |1 | | |38 ft long, 25 ft circumference.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article96507358|title = Whale washed ashore|date = 1953-07-15|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-11|newspaper = Northern Star}}</ref> |- |1953 |April 12 |{{Flagicon|Mexico}} Mexico |Cabo Tepoca, [[Sonora, Mexico|Sonora]] |9 | | |All bulls.<ref name=":3" /> |- |1953 |February 19 |{{Flagicon|New Zealand}} New Zealand |Maukau harbor, [[Auckland]] |1 |1 |0 |Stranded on mudbank. [[Auckland War Memorial Museum|Auckland War Memorial museum]] sought to obtain the skeleton.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article49254236|title = Whale is poser|date = 1953-02-20|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-10|newspaper = Barrier Miner}}</ref> |- |1949 |December |{{Flagicon|Denmark}} Denmark |[[Wadden Sea]] |5 |5 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1937 |July |{{Flagicon|France}} France |[[Dunkerque]] |2 |2 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1937 |February |{{Flagicon|Netherlands}} Netherlands |[[Terneuzen, Netherlands|Terneuzen]] |2 |2 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1936 |March 8 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |[[Stanley, Tasmania|Stanley]], Tasmania |1 |1 |0 |48 ft long. Claimed for 'salvage' by Captain W.E. Leggett.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article91797834|title = Stanley. The Whale|date = 1936-03-10|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-10|newspaper = Advocate}}</ref> Attempted to dispose away from settled areas towing the carcass behind a tugboat<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article91794306|title = Another effort to remove whale|date = 1936-03-19|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-10|newspaper = Advocate}}</ref> |- |1935 |November 25 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |West Inlet, [[Stanley, Tasmania|Stanley]], Tasmania |1 |1 |0 |23 ft long. Notes of amateur inspection published in newspaper.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article33310468|title = Sperm whale ashore|date = 1933-07-17|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-11|newspaper = The West Australian}}</ref> |- |1926 |December 27 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |[[Burleigh Heads]], Queensland |1 |1 |0 |Washed ashore dead. Bones purchased and displayed at museum<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article97921464|title=Burleigh whale sensation recalled|last=Harvey|first=John R.|date=1931-12-27|newspaper=Sunday Mail|location=Brisbane, Queensland}}</ref> |- |1913 |August ? |{{Flagicon|UK}}UK |[[Cornwall|Cornwall, England]] |50 |50 |0 |<ref>{{cite news|first=Jamie|last=Doward|title=Stranded whales provide new clues on the threats to sea creatures’ survival|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/jan/30/stranded-whales-opportunities-to-help-marine-life|newspaper=[[The Observer]]|location=London|date=2016-01-31|pages=20–21|accessdate=2016-02-01}}</ref> |- |1911 |March 11 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |[[Perkins Island]], Duck River, Tasmania |37 |37 |0 |All bulls but one, average length 50 ft.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article142940594|title = Stranded sperm whales at Perkins Island|date = 1911-03-11|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-10|newspaper = The Australasian}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article21207071|title = The Burleigh whale|date = 1927-12-22|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-10|newspaper = The Brisbane Courier}}</ref> The lone female was centrally positioned in the stranded group.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article142940556|title = Stranded whales|date = 1911-03-11|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-10|publisher = |newspaper = The Australasian}}</ref> |- |1908 |June 13 |{{Flagicon|USA}}USA |Mosquito Inlet, Florida |9 |9 |0 |Stranded on ebb tide. Whalers extracted oil from bodies.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1566318/nine_sperm_whales_strand_on_the_beach/|title = Nine sperm whales strand on the beach|date = 1908-06-20|work = |access-date = 2015-01-13|newspaper = The Daytona Gazette-News}}</ref> |- |1890 |August 21 |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Bald Hill, [[Port Wakefield, South Australia|Port Wakefield]], South Australia |1 |1 |0 |50 ft long, had been dead 'for some time'<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article91024039|title = A stranded whale|date = 1890-08-23|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-10|newspaper = South Australian Chronicle}}</ref> |- |1881 |November |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Point Bolingbroke, South Australia |1 |1 |0 |53 ft long.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article40067735|title = Little known Adelaide - the whale skeletons|date = 1935-08-17|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-10|newspaper = The Advertiser}}</ref> On display at the South Australian Museum. |- |1770 |December |{{Flagicon|Denmark}} Denmark |[[Hjarnø]] |2 |1 |1 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1872 |January |{{Flagicon|Australia}} Australia |[[Lipson Cove]], South Australia |1 |1 |0 |Plans were made to 'try out' and sell the oil.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article39271248|title = The whale at Lipson's Cove|date = 1872-01-18|work = |accessdate = 2014-12-10|newspaper = South Australian Register}}</ref> |- |1820 |April 17 |{{Flagicon|USA}}USA |New York, USA |1 | | |Single animal stranded near point of Sandy Hook, New York. School had been seen in the vicinity for at least ten days following 14 April.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sperm whales. New York, April 24 (1820) - on Newspapers.com|url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4404586/sperm_whales_new_york_april_24_1820/|website = Newspapers.com|access-date = 2016-02-23}}</ref> |- |1765 |January |{{Flagicon|Denmark}} Denmark |Bunken Strand |2 |2 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1762 |February |{{Flagicon|UK}} UK |Norfolk/Essex/Kent, England |12 |12 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1762 |January |{{Flagicon|Netherlands}} Netherlands |[[Frisian Islands]] |7-8 |7-8 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1762 |January |{{Flagicon|Germany}} Germany |[[Scharhörn]]/[[Neuwerk]] |2 |2 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1757 |February |{{Flagicon|Denmark}} Denmark |[[Fanø]] |3 |3 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1753 |February |{{Flagicon|UK}}UK |Findhorn, Scotland |3 |3 |0 |<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|url = http://www.vliz.be/imisdocs/publications/235238.pdf|title = Strandings of sperm whales Physeter macrocephalus in the North Sea: history and patterns|last = Smeenk|first = C.|date = 1997|journal = BULLETIN DE L'INSTITUT ROYAL DES SCIENCES NATURELLES DE BELGIQUE|accessdate = 2014-12-12|doi = |pmid = }}</ref> |- |1751 |March |{{Flagicon|Germany}} Germany |Oldeoog |2 |2 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1738 |January |{{Flagicon|Germany}} Germany |St Peter/Husum |3-4 |3-4 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1723 |December |{{Flagicon|Germany}} Germany |Neuwerk |21 |18 |3 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1617 |February |{{Flagicon|Netherlands}}Netherlands |Noordwijk |3+ |1 |2+ |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1617 |January |{{Flagicon|Netherlands}}Netherlands |Goeree |2 |2 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1604 |November |{{Flagicon|Germany}} Germany |Pellworm |2 |2 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1577 |November |{{Flagicon|Netherlands}}Netherlands |Ter Heijde |13-14 |3 |10-11 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1577 |July |Netherlands/Belgium |Schelde |3 |3 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |- |1572 |November |{{Flagicon|Denmark}} Denmark |Skallingen |3 |3 |0 |<ref name=":2" /> |}

revision.comment: Removal of the "Egypt-Sudan" subtitle - replaced with just "Egypt". Addition of "Nile" and "Lake Victoria" under international waterways. Addition/removal of links where appropriate.
revision.text:
{{short description|List of navigable rivers, canals, estuaries, lakes, and firths}} [[Image:Waterways world.png|thumb|Total length of waterways per country in kilometers]] This is a '''list of [[waterways]]''', defined as navigable [[river]]s, [[canal]]s, [[estuary|estuaries]], [[lake]]s, or [[firth]]s. In practice, and depending on the language, the term "waterway" covers maritime or inland transport routes, as suggested by "way". Wherever a free-flowing river cannot bear load-carrying vessels, the correct term is "watercourse", with no connotation of use for transportation of cargo. To be of practical use, the list distinguishes international maritime waterways (including ship canals), international inland waterways, then inland waterways, including canals and large lakes. {{TOC right}}
